From rajasuperman at gmail.com  Wed Mar  1 01:18:03 2006
From: rajasuperman at gmail.com (Raja Subramanian)
Date: Wed Mar  1 01:18:12 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Regarding raid and lvm
In-Reply-To: <92f9a9560602281146x5e50bf98ja41028619e3cae3f@mail.gmail.com>
References: <d37948920602270639o53ff581cn84fd37b263e05208@mail.gmail.com>
	<92f9a9560602281146x5e50bf98ja41028619e3cae3f@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <92f9a9560602281148i402ad1cdp160fca1cf9c09330@mail.gmail.com>

Hi,

On 2/27/06, veeraa bose <veeraaexp@gmail.com> wrote:
> we r having a  server,its having gentoo 2006.0 and kernel is 2.6.15 and
> complied with SATA HDD support.
> our current setup is 3 IDE HDD,
...

Your setup looks too complicated.  If you don't keep it simple, disaster
recovery will become a nightmare and _you_will_lose_data_.  I strongly
recommend that you change your setup.

There are two fundamental problems in your setup:
    1.  Too complex - mixing LVM and RAID.  Ask yourself if you
          really need these features, and trade it off for simplicity.
    2.  OS and data are not on separate HDDs.

Here is what I recommend:

    1.  Use a separate "system" disk (40-80GB IDE HDD) on which you load
         the entire OS.  I don't recommend soft RAID on your system disk.
         Ensure your computer has an CDROM (/dev/hdd).

    2.  For "data", use SATA and only RAID1 and RAID10.  Don't run RAID5.
            Eg. RAID1 (sda1, sdb1) = md0
                   RAID1 (sdc1, sdd1) = md1
                   RAID0 (md0, md1) = md2    (mount as /data/<hostmame>)

     3.  Forget LVM.  Soft RAID and LVM is too ugly.  Partition you disks
          correctly.

     4.  Ensure your HDDs have adequate airflow and are run cool.  If
           possible, invest in SATA enclosures
http://www.tigerdirect.com/applications/SearchTools/item-details.asp?EdpNo=1599963&CatId=285

Here is a sensible partitioning scheme to use:
System disk:
hda1  -  /rescue  -  1GB  (mini OS install for "rescue mode" only)
hda2  -  root       -  250MB
hda3  -  /usr       -  5GB
hda5  -  /var       -  2GB
hda6  -  /tmp      - 1.5GB
hda7  -  /data/local  - <rest-of-disk>
hda8  - swap      - 512MB (ideally your system will not touch swap)

First, install a minimal version of your OS in hda1.  You will boot from this
only if the system disk itself fails or hda2-8 become corrupt.

Reinstall the OS as usual in hda2-8.

Use backuppc (or other) backup software to secure your system disk.

Data disk:
Single partition that fills almost the entire disk.  Mount under
/data/<hostname>.

It's very important that you do not partition the entire disk.  In your 300GB
disks, partition only upto ~299GB and leave the final 1GB empty.  Reason
is that a Seagate 300GB HDD is not the same size as a Maxtor 300GB HDD
and is bad for mirroring where both disks are expected to be the same size.

I run close to 20 servers like this and am very happy with the results.

Hope this helps.

- Raja

Subject: [Ilugc] redirection request between interfaces(ath0 and eth0)
In-Reply-To: <E044F591B954D84186173DB5134357A13C6EA5@lexus.moschip.com>
References: <E044F591B954D84186173DB5134357A13C6EA4@lexus.moschip.com>
	<72a9b0620602272223m20f36dc5y928a3aa0dee45ec8@mail.gmail.com>
	<E044F591B954D84186173DB5134357A13C6EA5@lexus.moschip.com>
Message-ID: <92f9a9560602281204q5c347343o1e8ec17cb34a1182@mail.gmail.com>

Hi,

On 2/28/06, Raja M. <raja.mallik@moschip.com> wrote:
> If I ping 192.168.200.68 from A(PC1) , it work's.
>
> I want to access all the network nodes that are attached to point C(PC2).
>  As for your query proxy /arp are enabled.
>
> Also my local lan is configured for 192.168.200.0 network..

How are your routing tables setup on both sides?

_Every_ machine on your network needs one of the below routes.

On the WiLAN end, you need 192.168.11.1 as router for 192.168.200.x.
On the LAN end, you need 192.168.200.68 as router for 192.168.11.x.

Perhaps it's cleaner to use the same 192.168.200.x subnet for the
WiLAN as well?  Or maybe make the WiLAN AP as the default gateway
for both subnets.

- Raja

OK.
I  have boon going thro a lot of material for the last one week on related
matters.
The following are my understanding:

As the GNU/Linux is a community program, it is not very surprising to see a
bit of frictions here and there amongst the people contributing to the
progress. With the experience of being the cordinator for some community
programs, ( not s/w - national polio eradication),  i feel the best way to
look at (and deal with the situation) is to understand the different
interest groups with clarity.

Clash of interest is the most common problem in community programs since
most of the people contribute to the program just on/for  their interests
and not for commercial benefits.

The other common problem is clash of Ego.

In both the cases , some one in the group need to volunteer and  just grease
the area of heat and cool it down or just massage the egos that are clash if
needed. The key point to note is that  perfection in achieving the common
goal is the interest of the both the groups.

Here i would like to also point out that the Micro_oft interest group is not
seen in much action all thro, which i don't believe. Can not rule out the
possibility that, for a few ( or even many ) of the hearted ares in the
 GNU/Linux's development, the reason could have been an unidentifiable
instigation from the MS interest groups. For two reason

1. They are not small
2. They have huge business at stake.

RS
From prem at songbirdtech.com  Wed Mar  1 11:48:58 2006
From: prem at songbirdtech.com (Prem Kurian Philip)
Date: Wed Mar  1 11:49:09 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Reg QT Licensing
Message-ID: <1152.61.247.255.57.1141193938.squirrel@www.songbirdtech.com>

Hi,

>> 2. QT is licensed *per* developer, *per* platform. That is, if I purchase
>> a license for QT for a developer A, I cannot then have developer
>> B working on it even if developer A is no longer using this license.
>> Also, if I have QT installed on a computer and there are two people who
>> may use the *same* installation of QT, I must buy two licenses one for
>> each developer. Now if each developer develops on Linux as well as
>> Windows, I must buy a QT license for each developer for each platform. So
>> you can see how the costs add up.

>Right, I'll say that this is a real problem. But again, not with the GPL
>version.

Yes, its fine if all you are doing is GPL development; but companies like
to sell products because it pays salaries.

Not that GPLed products cannot be sold, it is just that there aren't too
many commercially successful purely GPLed products around. Please don't
say Linux, because companies don't really make money on Linux - companies
make some money on support, and the rest of the money is made on the
commercial products bundled along with Linux distributions - example RHEL,
Novell Enterprise Server etc which are all expensive because they bundle
commercial/proprietary products.

>> Now, I must add that I have absolutely no issues with paying for
>> licenses. Companies have the prerogative to charge what they want for the
>> products they sell.
>>
>> But having said that, the QT licensing scheme is just plain unattractive
>> to say the least - each license per developer per platform is in the
>> range of USD 1500+ and I cannot transfer licenses between developers, I
>> have to purchase multiple licenses for *each* machine for *each* platform
>> etc..

> There's the perfectly usable GPL version... I'm not going to close my
> sources, so why would I be interested in the closed license and how that
> affects some other dev?

Again, its fine for you. But I am not taking about you. I am talking about
companies who make products which sell. Here, I must add a correction to
what I stated earlier - it is possible to transfer commercial QT licenses
between developers but only once every 6 months. That is, if you have a
developer who is working on QT and he leaves the company, you cannot use
the same license for another developer without waiting for a further 6
months.

Please note that I am not claiming that Trolltech should give away their
code. I am perfectly fine with paying for software and I regularly
purchase some pretty expensive software. What I am refering to is the fact
that Trolltech charges too much and that their licensing schemes (such as
the developer specific licensing) is just very difficult to work with.

>> About the licensing - OSS vs commercial debates which are always on among
>> the OSS crowd - my advice is to not get religious about it and to just
>> use a license which is pragmatic.

> It's not about religion, at least on my side. All I care about is whether
> I can use the toolkit to develop applications under the license I choose,
> that being the GPL. I don't care that somebody who wants to make a closed
> source software can't take an *already released* software and close it,
> just by buying a Trolltech license. That's just dishonest.

Do you realize that many companies have GPL and non-GPLed editions of the
same software where the non-GPLed editions include some propreitary
extensions? Also, do you know that these companies sell the non-GPLed
editions? The commercial QT license explicitly forbids this. That is, once
a line of code is written using the QT GPL license, it can never be sold
by the same company which developed it even if the company purchases
commercial QT license.

Also, it may interest some to know that even the LGPL licensing of
libraries poses a legal problem on resource constrained embedded hardware
because the constraints imposed by the hardware do not make it feasible to
dynamically link to a library - that is, on these memory and processing
power constrained hardware which may not even include a dynamic library
loader, it becomes impossible to use a LGPL licensed library because the
LGPL license allows the use of these libraries with propreitary products
only if the library is linked to dynamically. That is, static linking to
these libraries are not allowed for propreitary software. If a software
links staticly to a LGPL software, then that software must also be
released under LGPL.

A lot of embedded solutions use LGPL licensed libraries in anycase, and
many link the propreitary software staticly with the LGPLed Libraries and
are actually violating the LGPL. Examples include many gaming consoles
which use LGPLed compression libraries for texture handling, glib routines
for stuff such as unicode and utf8 handling etc. I am not quoting any
names, but I am sure a few gaming consoles, PVRs etc come to mind
immediately.

Thanks,
Prem Kurian Philip
Songbird Technologies

> commercial products bundled along with Linux distributions - example RHEL,
> Novell Enterprise Server etc which are all expensive because they bundle
> commercial/proprietary products.

Fine. There's nothing wrong in looking for another license then. But there's a 
difference between bundling programs and trying to change a program from 
being GPL to being non-GPL.

> Again, its fine for you. But I am not taking about you. I am talking about
> companies who make products which sell. Here, I must add a correction to
> what I stated earlier - it is possible to transfer commercial QT licenses
> between developers but only once every 6 months. That is, if you have a
> developer who is working on QT and he leaves the company, you cannot use
> the same license for another developer without waiting for a further 6
> months.

OK, the specific terms of the non-GPL license are not exactly friendly. I 
don't dispute that.

> Please note that I am not claiming that Trolltech should give away their
> code. I am perfectly fine with paying for software and I regularly
> purchase some pretty expensive software. What I am refering to is the fact
> that Trolltech charges too much and that their licensing schemes (such as
> the developer specific licensing) is just very difficult to work with.

Why should this dissuade me from using Qt for my GPL code?

> Do you realize that many companies have GPL and non-GPLed editions of the
> same software where the non-GPLed editions include some propreitary
> extensions? Also, do you know that these companies sell the non-GPLed
> editions? The commercial QT license explicitly forbids this. That is, once
> a line of code is written using the QT GPL license, it can never be sold
> by the same company which developed it even if the company purchases
> commercial QT license.

That's a restriction of the GPL, not of the QTL, I think. The whole reason for 
the GPL is that nobody can close the source once it's been released under the 
GPL. The Qt license merely reaffirms this, I think. I don't think there's any 
excuse for releasing something under the GPL and then saying "I want to close 
it now". If you want it to be closed, do so from the beginning, or use 
something like the BSDL. I think BSDL (the new version, anyway) is GPL 
compatible, and that you can use the Qt opensource edition to write code in 
the BSDL. I don't know what happens after that, when you try to close the 
BSDL code, with respect to Qt, though.

> Also, it may interest some to know that even the LGPL licensing of
> libraries poses a legal problem on resource constrained embedded hardware
> because the constraints imposed by the hardware do not make it feasible to
> dynamically link to a library - that is, on these memory and processing
> power constrained hardware which may not even include a dynamic library
> loader, it becomes impossible to use a LGPL licensed library because the
> LGPL license allows the use of these libraries with propreitary products
> only if the library is linked to dynamically. That is, static linking to
> these libraries are not allowed for propreitary software. If a software
> links staticly to a LGPL software, then that software must also be
> released under LGPL.
>
> A lot of embedded solutions use LGPL licensed libraries in anycase, and
> many link the propreitary software staticly with the LGPLed Libraries and
> are actually violating the LGPL. Examples include many gaming consoles
> which use LGPLed compression libraries for texture handling, glib routines
> for stuff such as unicode and utf8 handling etc. I am not quoting any
> names, but I am sure a few gaming consoles, PVRs etc come to mind
> immediately.

Certainly. I know about this issue. The LGPL is there to allow dynamic 
linking...

In any case, I will personally continue to use Qt-opensource for my GPLed 
development, because I have no intention of ever closing it. If I ever need 
to develop closed-source Qt programs, that can come later.

Also, from the Qt site:

To transfer a license, *or if you need a more flexible licensing agreement*, 
please contact sales@trolltech.com. (emphasis mine)

I think they have a provision for negotiating a different license. I've got no 
idea how difficult using this would be, though.

Shash

There are many solutions:

1. set and export CC before proceeding:

 export CC=/path/to/gcc

2. Add the location where your gcc is installed to
PATH environment variable:

  PATH=$PATH:/path/to/

From rajasuperman at gmail.com  Wed Mar  1 21:59:39 2006
From: rajasuperman at gmail.com (Raja Subramanian)
Date: Wed Mar  1 21:59:50 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] redirection request between interfaces(ath0 and eth0)
In-Reply-To: <E044F591B954D84186173DB5134357A13C6EA6@lexus.moschip.com>
References: <E044F591B954D84186173DB5134357A13C6EA4@lexus.moschip.com>
	<72a9b0620602272223m20f36dc5y928a3aa0dee45ec8@mail.gmail.com>
	<E044F591B954D84186173DB5134357A13C6EA5@lexus.moschip.com>
	<92f9a9560602281204q5c347343o1e8ec17cb34a1182@mail.gmail.com>
	<E044F591B954D84186173DB5134357A13C6EA6@lexus.moschip.com>
Message-ID: <92f9a9560603010829u32a620bfhcd8fd14ba800d8ff@mail.gmail.com>

Hi,

On 3/1/06, Raja M. <raja.mallik@moschip.com> wrote:
>  As you said, I did in PC2.
...

>  route add -net 192.168.200.0 netmask 255.255.255.0 gw 192.168.11.1 dev ath0
>  route add -net 192.168.11.0 netmask 255.255.255.0 gw 192.168.200.68 dev
> eth0
...

>  My ping from PC2 stops to both subnet!

Doh!  The routes are not to be setup on PC2!!  You need to set it on the other
machines in your LAN so they can route packets through PC2.

Try pinging 192.168.11.11 from the 192.168.200.x subnet (but not from PC2), and
you'll find the packets heading off to the default gateway on the 192.168.200.x
network and not reaching PC2 at all.  There lies your problem.

You need to run the first route above command, but without the "dev
ath0" bit, on
all machines on your WiLan.  And conversely, you need to run the second route
command without the "dev eth0" bit on all machines in the wired LAN.

Absolutely no routing needs to be setup on PC2.  It's fine as is.


Alternately, hooking up the WiLAN card to the default gateway on 192.168.200.x
network should also do the trick.

- Raja

PS: Please don't top post.  And quote your replies nicely.

From km at mrna.tn.nic.in  Thu Mar  2 00:38:10 2006
From: km at mrna.tn.nic.in (km)
Date: Thu Mar  2 00:32:47 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Regarding raid and lvm
In-Reply-To: <92f9a9560602281148i402ad1cdp160fca1cf9c09330@mail.gmail.com>
References: <92f9a9560602281146x5e50bf98ja41028619e3cae3f@mail.gmail.com>
	<92f9a9560602281148i402ad1cdp160fca1cf9c09330@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060301190810.GA14138@mrna.tn.nic.in>

Hi all,

I am new to RAID configurations.
I have a system yet to be configured as database server with 3 x 144 SCSI disks in 'hardware'-RAID-5 with 8GB RAM.
Do i also need a separate harddisk to be used as a system  disk ? do i need to mount each disk as a single parition ? or can i sub partition the SCSI disks ?
what do u suggest ? 

regards,
KM

> Here is what I recommend:
> 
>     1.  Use a separate "system" disk (40-80GB IDE HDD) on which you load
>          the entire OS.  I don't recommend soft RAID on your system disk.
>          Ensure your computer has an CDROM (/dev/hdd).
> 
>     2.  For "data", use SATA and only RAID1 and RAID10.  Don't run RAID5.
>             Eg. RAID1 (sda1, sdb1) = md0
>                    RAID1 (sdc1, sdd1) = md1
>                    RAID0 (md0, md1) = md2    (mount as /data/<hostmame>)
> 
>      3.  Forget LVM.  Soft RAID and LVM is too ugly.  Partition you disks
>           correctly.
> 
>      4.  Ensure your HDDs have adequate airflow and are run cool.  If
>            possible, invest in SATA enclosures
> http://www.tigerdirect.com/applications/SearchTools/item-details.asp?EdpNo=1599963&CatId=285
> 
> Here is a sensible partitioning scheme to use:
> System disk:
> hda1  -  /rescue  -  1GB  (mini OS install for "rescue mode" only)
> hda2  -  root       -  250MB
> hda3  -  /usr       -  5GB
> hda5  -  /var       -  2GB
> hda6  -  /tmp      - 1.5GB
> hda7  -  /data/local  - <rest-of-disk>
> hda8  - swap      - 512MB (ideally your system will not touch swap)
> 
> First, install a minimal version of your OS in hda1.  You will boot from this
> only if the system disk itself fails or hda2-8 become corrupt.
> 
> Reinstall the OS as usual in hda2-8.
> 
> Use backuppc (or other) backup software to secure your system disk.
> 
> Data disk:
> Single partition that fills almost the entire disk.  Mount under
> /data/<hostname>.

Subject: [Ilugc] gtk+ need help

	<4405B3CD.6030905@naturesoft.net>

On Thu, 2006-03-02 at 10:40 +0530, Kenneth Gonsalves wrote:
> On Wednesday 01 Mar 2006 8:16 pm, suman adak wrote:
> > How to generate tree structure(like any file manager)? Which will
> > automatically create row according to the directory structure.
> 
> http://www.gtk.org/tutorial1.2/gtk_tut-12.html
> 

GtkTree is deprecated and now unsupported in GTK 2.0, It is known to be
buggy. To use it in GTK2.0, you must define the symbol GTK_ENABLE_BROKEN
prior to including the GTK+ header files.
http://www.gtk.org/tutorial2.0/

I do all my GNOME+GTK development with Glade, don't know much about
Anjuta IDE. AFAIK Anjuta is a promising young IDE that internally uses
libglade for code building. Also I really don't relay on Glade's code
building capability either. What I do is, create UI framework with
glade, and later do all coding and necessary build system changes all
through an external editor. For accessing the UI from the *.glade file
at runtime, I use libglade library.

There are two useful tool in fedora dist - devhelp and gtk-demo, which I
think will be help full.

-AT

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Thu Mar  2 21:13:28 2006

Subject: Creating initrd (was Re: [Ilugc] Hi)

Hi,

<quote>

--- U M A R <amu_314@yahoo.com> wrote:
 hi,
  It means i want to use my own OS not any other
  ready made OS.For example

> On 01/03/06, U M A R  wrote:
> > hi,
> > Whether any body tried to create your own

</quote>

Its called top-posting. Please don't do that in the
mailing list.

Use a meaningful subject line.

[What you see below is called bottom-posting. Always
use this when you reply to e-mail messages]

-- Umar <amu_314@yahoo.com> wrote:
> Only thing is i need to make my own initrd image...I

> want to know what and all it should contains. How i
> can build my own initrd....???

For 2.6 kernels:

During kernel build, you will do:

 make modules_install

This will install your modules to /lib/modules/2.6.x.

To create a initial ramdisk image do:

 mkinitrd -o initrd.img-2.6.x 2.6.x

Replace 2.6.x with your compiled kernel version. 

Initial ramdisk image is a temporary filesystem for
loading necessary modules during bootup. Initially
when the kernel boots there is no filesystem, but, you
want your driver modules to load and get initialised
during boot. Hence, the use of a ramdisk.

SK

putting forth my view)

True. But Saturday evening would make it a bit uncomfortable. When the
meet starts at 3 PM (actually, 3:30 PM most of the times), it goes on
up to even 6:30 most of the times. Now, if such a meet begins at 6:00
PM, I can certainly see many people having to reschedule dinner (I am
one of them!), and those without vehicles finding it a bit hard to get
home (I am here too!).

Sunday may be a good idea, though I am personally against it; for
Sunday is the best time to finish unfinished work, and, well I just
can't offer you the reason, but I wouldn't want to schedule anything
on Sunday. But if most people do want to come on a Sunday, I guess I
can make it, but then; with Monday lurking nearby, it just feels
odd...

However, as I said, let the majority prevail.

co-exist.Heck, I'll go ahead and say it.. Even the IIT's are not at
the same level that UCB/MIT were in the early 1980's.

Come to think of it, engineers being produced out of Factories today
really really need a Indian version of Bill Joy.It need'nt be a IIT
which delivers that.Future engineers today need a "hero" who delivers
on the Innovation front.

What Chennai based engineering colleges need is *one* annual event
spread over a week and kept trully academic and encompasses FOSS and
other (computer related technologies,Shaastra doesn't count).It neednt
be competetive.Maybe something held in June-July(hols!) wherein
students can meetup and present seminars/workshops/share idea's and
even showcase what they did for their annual projects.

I just wish the FOSS scene was better when I was a student.
</rant>

Anyway, keep up the good work guys..

-Toufeeq
PS: Above views are my own and not for public debate :P

Hi,

On 3/4/06, knaren@midascomm.com <knaren@midascomm.com> wrote:
> Me too trying something similar to this.

Sorry to nitpick, but addressing yourself "me" is bad english, and annoys
most people.

> What I want to do
> is to direct the mails reaching a user' mail account to a
> database table(MySQL).

Storing adhoc files in database tables (esp MySQL) is a bad idea.
Databases are not designed for this (ab)use.  Store the emails as files
and keep file names only in the DB.  That's a far better approach.

Believe me.  I hold ~300k emails, ~25GB table size and MySQL makes
me very unhappy.

- Raja

On 4.3.06 I had discussion with Arunai Engg College 
Faculty+management and Mr.Srinivasan of NRCFOSS,MIT. The following
decisions were made

1.Preparatory technical session. This will be held on 18th Mar 
instead of 19th as posted in List. This session will be confined
to about 25-30 students who will be volunteers for the LDD. This
will not have formal shape of a seminar. Instead ILUGC will
send 2-3 volunteers who will conduct hands on session to students
on installation, basic operations and intro to things which 
students can practice in one week and exhibit in the LDD. 
e.g Openoffice and other such office tools, browsers, 
multimedia tools line xine, educational software for school 
children etc.

2.Technical Seminar on 25th March: About 250-300 (the size of the
auditorium) will be attending the seminar. The participants will
be students from Arunai and few other engg/science colleges in and
around Thiruvannamalai. Only interested students will be asked to
attend seminar. The students will not be forced to  sit for the sake
of crowd. The topics will be decided by ILUGC. The exact schedule I
will post after consolidating the volunteers, the topics they chose
etc.

3.Public LDD on 26th March: The college authorities expect about
3000-4000 visitors. They will be giving publicity through media and
also by sending invitation/posters to colleges all over TN. There
will
be some 20 stalls allocated to us. They are trying to get some
sponsors also and they made need some stalls. However, all such
stalls
will be opensource related.

4.The college will provide facility for transportation, stay etc to
the ILUGC volunteers. By 18th we have to give how many of us will be
attending the 25th and 26th event. The travel time will be about 3
hours from MIT,Chromepet. From inside city it might be 1 hour more.
After consolidating the volunteer list let us decide ideal location
to
start.

5. The quality of technical session, demos etc are now the
responsibility of ILUGC, in what seems to me the biggest ever LDD
conducted by us. I request atleast 50 luggies to volunteer for the
events.

Raman.P

Balachandran Sivakumar wrote:

>                 I use Debian Sarge Linux.I usually my usb by giving the command
> mount /dev/sda1 /mnt/usb
> 
> But in another system i find tha the hard disk itsef is listed as
> sda1,sda5,sda6 (In the /etc/fstab file)....
> 
> So in such systems how do we mount the usb drives....

All USB devices are not given sda device node. It all depends on the
availabilty of the free SCSI bus(device). Just look out for dmesg output
after plugging in your USB device. The output when I connect my card
reader is something as follows which says that the device is attached to
sdd.

usb 5-5: new high speed USB device using ehci_hcd and address 2
Initializing USB Mass Storage driver...
scsi2 : SCSI emulation for USB Mass Storage devices
usbcore: registered new driver usb-storage
USB Mass Storage support registered.
usb-storage: device found at 2
usb-storage: waiting for device to settle before scanning
psmouse.c: GlidePoint at isa0060/serio4/input0 lost synchronization,
throwing 1 bytes away.
  Vendor: Generic   Model: USB SD Reader     Rev: 1.00
  Type:   Direct-Access                      ANSI SCSI revision: 00
sd 2:0:0:0: Attached scsi removable disk sdb
  Vendor: Generic   Model: USB CF Reader     Rev: 1.01
  Type:   Direct-Access                      ANSI SCSI revision: 00
sd 2:0:0:1: Attached scsi removable disk sdc
  Vendor: Generic   Model: USB SM Reader     Rev: 1.02
  Type:   Direct-Access                      ANSI SCSI revision: 00
SCSI device sdd: 256000 512-byte hdwr sectors (131 MB)
sdd: Write Protect is off
sdd: Mode Sense: 03 00 00 00
sdd: assuming drive cache: write through
SCSI device sdd: 256000 512-byte hdwr sectors (131 MB)
sdd: Write Protect is off
sdd: Mode Sense: 03 00 00 00
sdd: assuming drive cache: write through
 sdd: sdd1
sd 2:0:0:2: Attached scsi removable disk sdd
  Vendor: Generic   Model: USB MS Reader     Rev: 1.03
  Type:   Direct-Access                      ANSI SCSI revision: 00
sd 2:0:0:3: Attached scsi removable disk sde
usb-storage: device scan complete

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Sun Mar  5 04:56:15 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Sun Mar  5 18:26:32 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Mounting usb drives
In-Reply-To: <aec5a5f80603040917r35f53c83v768abae41b5c1d7f@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060305125615.89683.qmail@web50202.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi Balachandran and others,

--- Balachandran Sivakumar <contactsbala@gmail.com>
wrote:
>                 I use Debian Sarge Linux.

Which kernel? Open a terminal and post output of:

 /bin/uname -r

I use Debian Sarge with 2.6.12.3 kernel. Recent
distros with 2.6 kernels use udev, and they should
automatically mount the filesystem for you.

In 2.4 kernels devfs is used, and hence you will need
to mount the filesystem by checking the output of
/bin/dmesg for the device filename.

Which USB thumb drive?

SK

Subject: [Ilugc] Yoper BlackSand Release
Message-ID: <a54a308e0603051044r4b8ce7c2g9b10c6f7bbf47ab@mail.gmail.com>

*Yoper 3.0 Beta (Blacksand) released*

The team, together with lead-developer Tobias Gerschner, are proud to
announce the start of the public beta-testing phase of Yoper GNU/Linux.
After the last official 2.1 release (2004) and the last beta release
2.2(2005), things became quiet at Yoper. Andreas Girardet, the founder
and
long-time
developer of Yoper, resigned as Yoper lead developer in 2005 and handed over
the duties to Tobias Gerschner.

After rewriting all internal scripts, the inclusion of the Kanotix
hardware-detection, a completely overhauled command line installer, a brand
new GUI-installer (written from scratch) and several internal (and thus
unannounced) alpha-releases, the time for public beta-testing has come.

The 623 MB ISO-file includes Kernel 2.6.15, Xorg 6.8.2, etcnet, KDE 3.5.0,
Koffice, Firefox 1.5, Thunderbird 1.5 and lots of other cutting-edge
packages.

Yoper remains true to its philosophy: the best from all distributions. Fast
and easy to install, the fastest KDE Desktop out of the box, instantly ready
for work, optimized for i686 and compatible processors . It features SMART
as the package-manager and an optimized package-building procedure with a
new buildserver accessible to the public.

We, the Yoper team, would be pleased to receive strong community support
during our new betaphase-testing.

You can download the iso from here:
ftp://ftp.yoper.com/pub/yoper/devel/YOPER-2.91-BLACKSAND.iso

We are also looking for developers(freelancers) for Yoper Installer (YIS),
so friends who are interested to work in Installer Section, please mail
me.We have a very interesting Installer to work with.The languages used are
Python, Qt, Qt Designer and Bash Scripts.

--
Regards,
Chaks,
Yoper Ltd.
http://www.yoper.com
http://www.yoper.com/forum
--
The main aim of communication is clarity and simplicity. Simplicity means
focussed effort.

> > What I want to do

> Storing adhoc files in database tables (esp MySQL) is a bad idea.

database abuse). Then, i'm not trying to direct the entire
mail into the databse. I parse the mail, extract the
required infos say, from and to mail address, subject, time
and 160 bytes of actual mail. Then add these infos to the
database. I do this to build a email indication system for
a subscriber end integrated phone.

Hope i'm making myself clear. Presently i use procmail and
mailbox module of pyhton library to do this.

trying to configure my Sify BB internet connection
with it. I some how failed(unable to ping default
gateway). Please let me know where i am going wrong,

 Configured the eth0 interface with the static IP,
Primary DNS, Secondary DNS and the Default Gateway
which the ISP provided me.

  Checked with ifconfig command for ensuring my
configurations. It reflected those values.

 The eth0 connection shows active but still i am not
able ping the default gateway, ping returns
"Destination host unreachable". I tried doing it by
disabling firewall but did not work.

 I also checked the files in
/etc/sysconfig/network-scripts they seemed to have the
proper information.

 I also checked the default kernel IP routing table
using netstat -nr command.It seems to be fine.

 Traceroute to default gatewary shows something like
following

From sundaram at fedoraproject.org  Mon Mar  6 12:44:58 2006
From: sundaram at fedoraproject.org (Rahul Sundaram)
Date: Mon Mar  6 12:45:14 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] SMART and disk performance
In-Reply-To: <9a9bfc170603052310t4dc6e4e3h8529ce3e80bda5e5@mail.gmail.com>
References: <9a9bfc170603052310t4dc6e4e3h8529ce3e80bda5e5@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <440BE172.3030003@fedoraproject.org>

Ramkumar R wrote:

>Hi!
>
>Does anyone here know whether enabling SMART on a IDE disk decreases
>the performance (I/O rate, latency etc.) of the disk? In general, are
>there any tradeoffs involved?
>
It does have a performance tradeoff but nothing significant compared to 
a potential data loss.

> And how effective/important is using
>something like smartd for a single user desktop?
>
Depends on the importance of the data on your system. Of course you 
wouldnt just rely on smart and do regular backups if you care about that.

>Are there any special
>issues involved in the case of laptops (like power consumption etc.)?
>  
>
Additional checks would consume more power but these are trivial.  Smart 
is generally useful for servers where a failing storage device needs to 
be phased out and replaced in a planned manner.


-- 
Rahul

Hi Gokul,

--- Gokul Kannan Jeyapaul <gjeyapau@yahoo.co.in>
wrote:
>  I installed fedora core 4, in my system and was
> trying to configure my Sify BB internet connection
> with it. 

What is the network setup? Is it a USB-based modem or
ethernet-based modem.

Is your connection a Plain Old Telephone System
dial-up or is it ADSL technology?

If its plain old dial-up, you will need to use KPPP or
wvdial.

If its ADSL, PPP over Ethernet, then you can use the
roaring penguin client, rp-pppoe (adsl-start,
adsl-stop , etc.).

On Monday 06 March 2006 14:55, suman adak wrote:
> hi all,
SNIP
> I have p4 1.8 GHz system with 128 MB  RAM. But when i tried install SUSE
> 9.3. it was installed but it was so slow that i could not able to run
> multiple task at a time. I think it is only for memory leakeage. Then i
> stated thinking  what should i do...
SNIP

Well, I'd not consider that "old hardware"... My first Linux install was an 
old RH 5.0 on a P1 100MHz with 32 MB RAM. I also recently installed Ubuntu 
5.10 on a P1 233MHz Toshiba Tecra laptop with 96 MB RAM, and my first Gentoo 
installation was on a P3 933 with 128 RAM. That install is still more or less 
alive, though transplanted to another system. Openoffice, KDE or Gnome and 
everything else on the last two systems...

What I'm trying to say is that nothing above the P2 level is really "old" 
hardware as far as installing most things goes. It'll be dog slow, and half 
the features won't work, but you can install it without trouble. And there 
are a lot of stories about 486s and early Pentiums still running web servers 
Out There. Throwing away hardware just because it's not cutting edge is 
simply wasteful.

Shash

From krish.arava at gmail.com  Mon Mar  6 21:11:29 2006
From: krish.arava at gmail.com (krishna chaitanya arava)
Date: Mon Mar  6 21:11:39 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: Problem connecting Fedora Linux to Sify Broadband
Message-ID: <feff2f50603060741l2ac98e9cqb096a226f611175b@mail.gmail.com>

Hi ,

I had similar problem few days ago . But I resolved it !!

Sify client for Linux is poorly written . Sify client doesnt connect to the
sify server for authentication on all Linux based OS.

But I came across a command line sify client for Windows called supersify

http://broadbandforum.in/sify/supersify/

I used Wine binary along with supersify . Guess what happend next!! It
worked .

Supersify is command based and accepts arguments for username , password and
MAC address also

ex:
wine supersify.exe -u "username" -p password -m macaddress -o ( for login )

wine supersify.exe -u "username" -p password -m macaddress -l ( for logout )

Note: Sify will allow you to connect if and only if you supply the MAC
address . So just type "ifconfig" to get your MAC address and supply it
along with the argument(-m)

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Tue Mar  7 09:38:46 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Tue Mar  7 23:09:14 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] help needed in installing RTLinux
In-Reply-To: <9fe99c5a0603070824v5913f795pf1bee56d839db6d7@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060307173846.52276.qmail@web50201.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi Srinivas,

--- srinivas p <linux.goalie@gmail.com> wrote:
> i have compiled and the kernel, but it is not
> booting, 

What is your hardware? Any error/output messages?

> can any body suggess
> me what to do,
> is there any method to install RTLinux
> how to add a RTLinux patch to our kernel, 

If your current kernel version is different from the
patched kernel, then you need to create one, manually.

Make a copy of your current kernel sources. Make
necessary changes and create a patch using:

 diff -urn original.sources/ patched.sources/ >
patch-file.txt

To apply the patch enter into the original.sources
directory, and do:

 cd /path/to/original.sources
 patch -p0 < /path/to/patch-file.txt

SK

From binand at gmail.com  Tue Mar  7 14:15:07 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Wed Mar  8 00:45:15 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] RAID5 config
In-Reply-To: <20060307160757.GA23813@mrna.tn.nic.in>
References: <20060307160757.GA23813@mrna.tn.nic.in>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610603071115o5b5bb13cr@mail.gmail.com>

On 07/03/06, km <km@mrna.tn.nic.in> wrote:
>  I have 3 SCSI hard disks to be configured on RAID-5  with hardware raid controller for data. Do i need to have Linux OS separately on an additional disk (apart from the 3 HDDs)? Can anyone suggest a good raid-5 config with OS partitions?

Depends on what level of resilience you are looking for. Is 100%
uptime a criterion? Then you need to keep your OS on at least RAID1
mirrored disks. Is it just data availability? Then the OS can be on a
non-RAID disk with the data on RAID5 arrays.

>  i have read abt software raid configuration. but donot know how different it is from hardware raid config.

Typically the controller vendor would have a management program (with
or without a Linux version). Even more typically, the management
program would be closed source. This is one of the points of
contention between the OpenBSD guys and other Free Unix/Unix clone
developers (FreeBSD, Linux etc.).

For example, I use the HP SmartArray 6i controller on my servers. They
come with a management program called, very innovatively, Array
Configuration Utility (ACU). I can define RAID levels, manage the
disks, look up status, change RAID level losslessly and generally, a
lot of things using this management program. The SCSI disks are in a
StorageWorks 14-drive array, adding up to about 850 GB of RAID5
storage. That takes care of the data, and since I also need 100%
uptime, I have a separate pair of disks on my server (Proliant DL380)
in RAID1 (hanging off the same controller) that has my Linux
installation.

Binand

From binand at gmail.com  Wed Mar  8 06:32:28 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Wed Mar  8 17:02:39 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] RAID5 config
In-Reply-To: <20060308101406.GA30668@mrna.tn.nic.in>
References: <20060307160757.GA23813@mrna.tn.nic.in>
	<d2a92d610603071115o5b5bb13cr@mail.gmail.com>
	<20060308101406.GA30668@mrna.tn.nic.in>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610603080332o6d453122o@mail.gmail.com>

On 08/03/06, km <km@mrna.tn.nic.in> wrote:
> The RAID5 setup is for hosting a database. data availability is the primary criterion. i will be storing only the database and related data in the raid disks.
> how do i plan to setup a nonraid disk for OS (linux) and data disks on RAID5.
>
> From googling i knew that hardware raid disks are seen as a single disk for the OS after setting raid5 from BIOS. Then where is the parity info stored in the disks assuming that each of the raid5 disks are wholly single partition.

In RAID5, one disk will be used entirely to store the parity
information. Thus with n disks in RAID5, you get storage worth
(n-1)*size of 1 disk.

>
> how can i plan the OS partitions  and raid disks ? Now if i use 3 SCSI in raid5 and a nonraid disk for OS then should i use software raid to connect both ?

These hardware RAID controllers will present the arrays to the host OS
- sometimes as regular SCSI drives (/dev/sda or so) or as specialized
devices (/dev/cciss/c0d0, for example). Your regular OS disk will be
presented by its driver - say /dev/sdb. It might be a good idea to use
a live CD distro to see the exact details.

If you have a off-the-shelf server, just boot it normally and use its
first-boot configuration program to setup RAID the way you desire. If
not, I'd recommend disconnecting the disks/arrays you intend to be in
RAID5, install the OS as usual, connect these disks, configure RAID
and then mkfs.whatever.

I'd recommend RHEL4 for a distro.

Binand

Hope this is the problem of finding the path of pkg-config. If your are installing gtk from /usr/local the path of pkg-config can be taken as /usr/local/bin and the path of gtk+2.0.pc is /usr/local. If your are installing it in /usr the path of pkg-config is /usr/bin and path of
gtk+2.0.pc is /usr. Try to set the path of pkg-config accordingly.

On 3/8/06, balachandar muruganantham <mbchandar@gmail.com> wrote:
> hi,
>
> i tried compiling thunderbird. i am struck with pango. it asked me to
> compile gtk+-2.0.0, glib-2.0.0,atk-1.0.0,pango-1.0.0
>
> i compiled glib-2 and installed. now while compiling pango-1.0.0, it
> asks me for glib-2
> below is the message
>
> checking for GLIB - version >= 2.0.0... no
> *** Could not run GLIB test program, checking why...
> *** The test program failed to compile or link. See the file config.log for the
> *** exact error that occured. This usually means GLIB was incorrectly installed
> *** or that you have moved GLIB since it was installed. In the latter case, you
> *** may want to edit the pkg-config script: /usr/bin/pkg-config
> configure: error:
> *** Glib 2.0.0 or better is required. The latest version of
> *** Glib is always available from ftp://ftp.gtk.org/.
>
> how shall i proceed then?

Since you have compiled glib-2 yourself (and assuming you haven't
provided a prefix), it would be installed under /usr/local.  So, set
the PKG_CONFIG_PATH accordingly for this to work.

shell> export PKG_CONFIG_PATH=/usr/local/lib/pkgconfig:/usr/lib/pkgconfig

HTH

Gopalarathnam Venkatesan

On 08/03/06, km <km@mrna.tn.nic.in> wrote:
> So i have planned to setup 3 SCSI disks in hardware-raid5 and one OS disk separately.

Good. Anyway, with 3 disks, RAID5 is the optimal solution. :)

> Assuming that /dev/sda is the hardware-raid5 (3 SCSI disks)  array presented to the host OS, if i fill data onto the raid5 array, how do i know  which raid5-SCSI array disk holds that data (excepting one of the raid5 disk which stores parity info) or its hidden from the OS point of view?

The OS should not be concerned with that. The controller or driver
should implement data storage techniques and could even depend on data
access conditions.

> what abt fedora4 x86-64 bit edition ? what other Linux flavours do one recommend ?
> what abt chunk size setting especially when i use reiserfs ?

> Hi Srinivas,
>
> --- srinivas p <linux.goalie@gmail.com> wrote:
> > i have compiled and the kernel, but it is not
> > booting,
>
> What is your hardware? Any error/output messages?
>
> > can any body suggess
> > me what to do,
> > is there any method to install RTLinux
> > how to add a RTLinux patch to our kernel,
>
> If your current kernel version is different from the
> patched kernel, then you need to create one, manually.
>
> Make a copy of your current kernel sources. Make
> necessary changes and create a patch using:
>
> diff -urn original.sources/ patched.sources/ >
> patch-file.txt
>
> To apply the patch enter into the original.sources
> directory, and do:
>
> cd /path/to/original.sources
> patch -p0 < /path/to/patch-file.txt
>
> SK

> On 07/03/06, km <km@mrna.tn.nic.in> wrote:
> >  I have 3 SCSI hard disks to be configured on RAID-5  with hardware raid
> controller for data. Do i need to have Linux OS separately on an additional
> disk (apart from the 3 HDDs)? Can anyone suggest a good raid-5 config with
> OS partitions?
>
> Depends on what level of resilience you are looking for. Is 100%
> uptime a criterion? Then you need to keep your OS on at least RAID1
> mirrored disks. Is it just data availability? Then the OS can be on a
> non-RAID disk with the data on RAID5 arrays.
>
> >  i have read abt software raid configuration. but donot know how
> different it is from hardware raid config.
>
> Typically the controller vendor would have a management program (with
> or without a Linux version). Even more typically, the management
> program would be closed source. This is one of the points of
> contention between the OpenBSD guys and other Free Unix/Unix clone
> developers (FreeBSD, Linux etc.).
>
> For example, I use the HP SmartArray 6i controller on my servers. They
> come with a management program called, very innovatively, Array
> Configuration Utility (ACU). I can define RAID levels, manage the
> disks, look up status, change RAID level losslessly and generally, a
> lot of things using this management program. The SCSI disks are in a
> StorageWorks 14-drive array, adding up to about 850 GB of RAID5
> storage. That takes care of the data, and since I also need 100%
> uptime, I have a separate pair of disks on my server (Proliant DL380)
> in RAID1 (hanging off the same controller) that has my Linux
> installation.
>
> Binand
>

From rajasuperman at gmail.com  Thu Mar  9 08:06:46 2006
From: rajasuperman at gmail.com (Raja Subramanian)
Date: Thu Mar  9 08:06:54 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] RAID5 config
In-Reply-To: <20060308152135.GA308@mrna.tn.nic.in>
References: <20060308101406.GA30668@mrna.tn.nic.in>
	<d2a92d610603080332o6d453122o@mail.gmail.com>
	<20060308152135.GA308@mrna.tn.nic.in>
Message-ID: <92f9a9560603081836s5a804c91mb85f3813aabd53d7@mail.gmail.com>

Hi,

On 3/8/06, km <km@mrna.tn.nic.in> wrote:
> Assuming that /dev/sda is the hardware-raid5 (3 SCSI disks)  array presented to the host OS, if i fill data onto the raid5 array, how do i know  which raid5-SCSI array disk holds that data (excepting one of the raid5 disk which stores parity info) or its hidden from the OS point of view?

RAID5 does not store parity information on a single physical disk.  Parity is
spread over all the disks in your array.

Whenever a disk block on a RAID 5 array is written, the parity information
needs to be recomputed and updated - results in a parity disk read and write
operation. If you had all the parity on a single disk (as in RAID4), the write
speed of your entire array reduces to the speed of your parity disk.

Therefore in RAID5, the parity blocks are distributed throughout the entire
array.  This eliminates the parity disk from becoming a bottleneck.

Eg. For disk block 1, the parity could be on physical disk disk 1.  For block 2,
the parity is on disk 2, and so on.  For disk block 4, parity is on disk 1.


However, this also increases complexity during disaster recovery.  If the
RAID controller goes fubar, and even if you know the on-disk data structures
of your proprietary RAID controller, manually recovery is virtually impossible.
In a RAID1 or RAID10 system, the task is far easier.

Further,  RAID1 and RAID10 avoid the expensive parity computation and this
makes software RAID much more practical.  Rebuild time in RAID5 arrays
is proportional to the size of the entire array.  For large arrays, this may be
several hours, and for this reason many SAN vendors do not use RAID5.

The downside with RAID1 or RAID10 is that you lose 50% of disk capacity
for redundancy.  With RAID5 the overheads are far smaller.  If you can
tolerate such high overhead, I would recommend RAID1, but it does not
sit nicely with your 3 disk configuration.  You need to think through this a bit
more.

One of the machines I run is an IBM server with Adaptec RAID and 8 ~150GB
SCSI HDDs.  If the machine dies, I'm totally at IBM's mercy for a replacement.
And until the replacement arrives, I can't in any way make the data
available for
production.  For those who've signed expensive IBM AMCs I suppose this is
less of an issue.

Software RAID on commodity hardware (NForce/Intel ICH6/8, SATA HDDs)
looks like a very attractive/safe alternative.  If the machine does down, just
pull out your HDDs and plug them into any old machine and you are back
online.

You're completely in control of both the software (linux) and the hardware
(commodity).  I that's exactly how I'd want it to be.

Ofcourse, these are just my views.  You need to figure out what's best for
your situation.

- Raja

Hi,

On 3/8/06, km <km@mrna.tn.nic.in> wrote:
> what abt fedora4 x86-64 bit edition ? what other Linux flavours do one recommend ?

Debian?  But the 64bit port is not yet ready for production use.  If
you can live
without 64bit features, Debian offers you and endless stream of
excellent quality
packages.  Apt makes software installation, upgrades and system maintenance
a breeze.

If your primary intent is to run proprietary software - Oracle, etc. -
then it's wise
to go with your vendor's recommendation.


> what abt chunk size setting especially when i use reiserfs ?

Reiserfs always uses a 4k block size.  Nothing to tune here.

Choosing the wrong RAID chunk size can kill performance.  The only way to
be sure is to try various RAID chunk sizes and benchmark. Bonnie is your friend.

- Raja

'rsync' command is good. You could also put important directories 
under version control with subversion. And to do all this 
automatically at regular intervals, the 'cron' command is 
essential. The syntax of these commands can be got my using the man 
pages, example:
man tar
man rsync
man cron

    1.  Top posting is evil
    2.  Top posting is evil
    3.  Top posting is evil

On 3/9/06, sami nathan <meetsami@gmail.com> wrote:
> Anyone plz tell me Backup and Recovery issues in Linux,
>
> I mean what to do to implement, I dont know anything about Bacukp tools,

For data, use rdiff-backup.  It's excellent for backing up huge quantities of
data - we hold ~1.5TB on rdiff-backup.  Increments are very space efficient,
and recovery is easy.

If you have a lot of machines, use backuppc (backuppc.sf.net) for OS and
application backup.  For data continue with rdiff-backup.

Note, both backup apps work best with HDDs and not tape.

- Raja

This problem has been reported by many with Realtek
card using the 8139too driver.

Lot of packets get queued without being serviced in
time.

http://www.linuxquestions.org/questions/showthread.php?threadid=164160

http://www.ussg.iu.edu/hypermail/linux/kernel/0310.2/0013.html

http://linux.derkeiler.com/Mailing-Lists/Kernel/2003-08/3187.html

On 09/03/06, Raja Subramanian <rajasuperman@gmail.com> wrote:
> Hi,
>
> On 3/8/06, km <km@mrna.tn.nic.in> wrote:
> > Assuming that /dev/sda is the hardware-raid5 (3 SCSI disks)  array presented to the host OS, if i fill data onto the raid5 array, how do i know  which raid5-SCSI array disk holds that data (excepting one of the raid5 disk which stores parity info) or its hidden from the OS point of view?
>
> RAID5 does not store parity information on a single physical disk.  Parity is
> spread over all the disks in your array.

Yep, my mistake. Sorry for misleading the OP. The reason for reserving
one disk is to keep that disk as spare; since in RAID5, the loss of
TWO disks in a RAID5 array leads to complete data loss in the array.

Binand

README.TXT
Smart Link Ltd.
http://www.smlink.com
Sep 30, 2003


Smart Link Soft Modem for Linux
-------------------------------


Introduction
============

This is Smart Link Soft Modem for Linux version 2.9. It provides
full-featured 56K Voice Fax Modem.
This is implemented as generic application (slmodemd) and set of
hardware specific kernel-space drivers (slamr, slusb).
ALSA modem drivers may be used instead of proprietary ones (see ALSA mode).

Features
========

Modem: V.92, V.90, V.34, V.32bis, V.32, V.23, V.22, V.21, Bell 103/212.
Flow control: V.42.
Compression: V.44, V.42bis.
Fax: Class 1.
Voice: V253 like modem.
Multiple modems are supported.


Supported Hardware
==================

HAMR5600 based AMR/CNR/MDC/ACR modem cards on the following Southbridge
chips:
- Intel ICH0,ICH2, ICH3, ICH4
- Via 686A, 686B, 8231, 8233
- SiS 630
- ALI 1535.
SmartPCI56/561/562/563 based PCI modem cards.
SmartUSB56 based USB modem.



Requirements
============

CPU: Intel Pentium II, Celron. AMD K6, Cyrix 500MHz or higher.
Memory: 64MB.

OS: Linux 2.4. You need the kernel header files at least (or full kernel
               source tree) installed and configured.
    Linux 2.6. You need the full kernel source tree installed and
configured.

Note: Most Linux Distributions have 'ready to use' kernel source package -
      be sure that this is installed.


Installation
============

1. Unpack tar.gz package file:

    $ gzip -dc slmodem-2.9.X.tar.gz | tar xf -

2. 'cd' to package directory:

    $ cd slmodem-2.9.X

3. Review and edit 'Makefile' (if need):

   In many cases you will need to correct path to your local kernel
   source tree:

        KERNEL_DIR=/path/to/linux

   Default KERNEL_DIR is '/lib/modules/<kerne-version>/build'. Many Linux
   Distributions use directory '/usr/src/linux-<version>' also.

   Note: If you are using Linux kernel 2.4, only header files should be
         available for build in $(KERNEL_DIR)/include

   Another way to pass right value KERNEL_DIR is to use command line
   parameter while running 'make':

        $ make KERNEL_DIR=/path/to/linux ...

4. Run 'make' command to compile package:

    $ make

5. Install. As 'root' user run:

    # make install

   It will install:

   - application 'slmodemd' under '/usr/sbin' directory

   - hardware specific drivers (kernel modules) 'slamr' and 'slusb'
     under conventional kernel modules directory

   - character device nodes '/dev/slamr0-3' with major number 212
     (for pci modems) and '/dev/slusb0-3' with major number 213
     (for usb modems).

   - config modules for autoloading (by editing file '/etc/modules.conf')
     (only with 2.4 kernels)

6. Config modem country.

   Use AT+GCI=<T.35 country code> command to setup country.

   Also you can setup default modem country by passing command line
   parameter '--country=MY_COUNTRY' to program 'slmodemd'.

   See output of 'slmodemd --countrylist' for a list of supported
   country names and T.35 country codes (see also 'slmodemd --help').

   Note: Command ATI7 shows currently installed country setting.

8. Uninstallation.

   In package directory just type:

    # make uninstall


Getting Started
===============

After successful installation and configuration:

1. Load modem driver.

   Load your modem hardware specific kernel module:

    # modprobe slamr

   if you are using AMR/CNR/PCI modem, or

    # modprobe slusb

   if you are using SmartUSB56 Modem.

   Note: this will be done automatically when modules were
         configured for 'loading on demand'

   Note: this is safe to load both 'alamr' and 'slusb' modules.

2. Run soft modem application.

       # /usr/sbin/slmodemd [options] <device_name>

   Where device name is appropriate device node for your modem
   (look at output of 'dmesg' command).
   Run '/usr/sbin/slmodemd --help' for details.

   Examples:

       # /usr/sbin/slmodemd --country=USA /dev/slamr0

   , or for SmartUSB56 Modems:

       # /usr/sbin/slmodemd --country=ITALY /dev/slusb0

3. Using the modem.

   When 'slmodemd' is running this creates PTY (pseudo-terminal) to
   emulate modem port device, also this creates symbolic link
   like '/dev/ttySL0' (shown at startup).

   Config your application to use this link '/dev/ttySL0' (or PTY node
   itself) as modem port.

   Note: Some application want 'to know' that they are working with
         pseudo-terminal and may require additional configurations.

   Known application notes:

   - 'wvdial' requires option 'Carrier Check = no' in config file

   - some versions of 'kppp' may not work properly with devices named
     like '/dev/ttySL0'. To workaround this you may create symbolic link
     '/dev/modem' ( # ln -s /dev/ttySL0 /dev/modem ) and use this link
     as modem device with 'kppp'

4. Startup automation.

    There are examples of startup scripts in 'scripts' directory.


ALSA mode
=========

ALSA has the built-in modem drivers included in 'alsa-driver' >= 1.0.2
and in Linux kernel >= 2.6.5. Currently there is 'intel8x0m' (snd-intel8x0m)
modem driver, which supports ICH based AC97 modems (MC97).

1. Configure your kernel and enable ALSA and ICH based modem support
   ( 'Device Drivers' -> 'Sound' -> 'Advanced Linux Sound Architecture' ->
     'PCI devices' -> 'Intel i8x0/MX440; AMD768/8111 modems' ) .

2. Build and install kernel and modules as usual (make , make
modules_install,
   etc.). ICH modem driver modem module name is 'snd-intel8x0m'
  (if was configured as module).

3. Build application 'slmodemd' with ALSA support. For this in
   slmodem-2.9.x dir:

      $ cd modem
      $ make SUPPORT_ALSA=1

   This will build 'slmodemd' with ALSA support. If compilation is failed
   review Makefile (near ALSA_SUPPORT condition) and define right library
   and/or CFLAGS

4. Use option '--alsa' when running 'slmodemd' and ALSA conventional
   device name ('hw:0' or 'hw:1' for instance). If modem support in
   the kernel was enabled as module module 'snd-intel8x0m' should be loaded.
   When using ALSA modem driver you don't need to load other modules
('slamr').


Troubleshooting
===============

If you get an error message during installation/configuration or loading
the modules try to see it in FAQ file.

Please report the problem to your modem provider or to us
(linux-support@smlink.com).


Feedback
========

Please send any feedbacks to Smart Link. See the Smart Link
web site for contact information (www.smlink.com) or to
linux-support@smlink.com.

> As the System is 2 processor based, my vendor offers me 1yr valid RHEL AS edition as OS with 2 CPU centric license. Is the edition ur refering to diferent from this ? or can i opt for 5 yr based licensing. i havent seen any 2 CPU based licenses on redhat.com.

Let us get the terminology clear. The software of RHEL is Free
Software. There is no licensing of that software involved here. You
are paying for support for that software from Redhat. What your vendor
is offering you is this support for one year. It is the same thing
whether you buy from vendor or from Redhat's website, and the cost is
cumulative when you buy for many years together (I think). The support
is per computer - not based on number of CPUs. Secondly, you can
upgrade from RHEL4 to RHEL5 as and when it comes out and still
continue to use the same support subscription.

Binand

Greetings!

I had this query which i asked on #linux-india (irc.freenode.net) I have
posted the log on http://prash.be/files/irc.log , but I am still unclear
on this. Could someone help me clear this up?

The CPU can run only 1 process at a time.
The Kernel is not a process.
On booting, the bootloader loads the kernel image into the memory and
give it the CPU control. This in turn starts the swapper process and the
subsequent processes. Now from what i understand from the conversation I
had on the irc channel is that at each context switch the scheduler
(which is part of the kernel) will generate a software interrupt.

My question is that when a process (say A) is in running state then the
scheduler will not have the CPU control to generate the software
interrupt. So how does context switching take place?

Thank You,
-- 
Prashanth Mohan
http://prashblog.be

a fixed version of the BLACKSAND ISO is released , providing fixes in

Google for more howtos.

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Sat Mar 11 19:51:52 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Sun Mar 12 09:22:09 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Whenever I start GUI , my system hangs..... Help !  
In-Reply-To: <20060311074739.45184.qmail@web31405.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20060312035152.97311.qmail@web50212.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi Manoj,

--- S K Manoj <skmanoj_cse@yahoo.com> wrote:
>   I had installed FC3 in my system. Post
> installation was not complete. Because,  FC3 does
> not detects my monitor and it says: Unknown Monitor.

Probably FC3 doesn't have the driver for your display
or your X is not configured. You can reconfigure your
X setting by running either xorgconfig (or xorgcfg -
GUI based) if using Xorg, or using xf86config (or
xf86cfg - GUI based) if using XFree86 after you login
to the console.

Not sure what the FC3 specific command for
reconfiguring X is. The above are generic commands for
X server re-configuration.

When you run the above commands, your configuration
will be saved in the configuration files
/etc/X11/xorg.conf or /etc/X11/X86Config respectively.


HTH,

SK

Subject: [Ilugc] FSF talk, FISAT, Angamaly, Kochi, Kerala
Message-ID: <20060312042019.35561.qmail@web50202.mail.yahoo.com>

Greetings!

* The final day of "Bharatham 2006" on Saturday March
12, 2006 at Federal Institute of Science and
Technology, Angamaly, Kochi, Kerala was cancelled due
to a fatal accident, the previous night, to students
from a nearby college. After the cultural festival on
Friday night, the students had left in their car at
around 2230. They didn't have control of the car at
one turning near a small bridge, skidded across, and
drowned in the river. The doors were locked and had
got jammed. Out of five students, only one managed to
escape. A tragedy to all students, faculty, friends in
and around Angamaly.

* Since I had come all the way, they just wanted me to
conduct an informal session for few minutes to the
faculty and few students who were there. I spoke on
free software and GNU/Linux. As a mark of respect to
the loss of life, I didn't take any photographs.

* I spent the remaining time with the students there,
and got to know more about free software activities in
Kerala, right from Calicut, to Palghat, Trichur,
Angamaly, Kochin, Kollam, Thiruvananthapuram.

* Pramode (http://pramode.net/) is the inspiration in
Government Engineering College, Trichur and other
places in Kerala.

* Space Kerala promote free software and do good work
in promoting the same to schools, colleges, NGOs
throughout Kerala: http://space-kerala.org/.

* Thanks to Sumod (final year, ICE) for coordinating
with me for the past three weeks, and for the
hospitality offered.

We want to collaborate more with our folks in Kerala
and will organize more workshops in future. 

Regards,

SK

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Sun Mar 12 09:05:52 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Sun Mar 12 22:36:04 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] I am unable to access my USB Flash drive in Fedora Core
	4. Help Me!
In-Reply-To: <20060312165657.24644.qmail@web31412.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20060312170552.41826.qmail@web50211.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi Manoj,

--- S K Manoj <skmanoj_cse@yahoo.com> wrote:
>   1) It does not detects my mouse.

... and please tell us what mouse you are using.

>   2) I am unable to access my USB flash drive.

... and please tell us what USB flash drive you are
using.
 
>   I explored /dev/ directory but I am unable to find
> a corresponding device.

If using a recent distro with 2.6 kernel, unless the
device is properly detected udevd (running on your
system) will not create the /dev entries for your
drive.

>   kernel: SCSI device sda: Unknown partition table 

It doesn't detect your partition table properly. What
filesystem are you using on the drive? Probably the
filesystem support is not available in the in-built
kernel you are using.

>   ***** I think the last message is important. I
> guess it automatically resets the device.

Host controller will always send a reset to the
device.

SK

From vamlists at gmx.net  Mon Mar 13 12:30:09 2006
From: vamlists at gmx.net (Vamsee Kanakala)
Date: Mon Mar 13 12:30:43 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [OT] Chennai.rb needs a meeting place
Message-ID: <44151879.8060007@gmx.net>

Hi All,

        Chennai.rb has benefited a lot from ILUGC, in building up its 
initial members from this list. I am very grateful for that, and hope 
many more ILUGC members discover the joy that is Ruby. I hope you guys 
wouldn't mind one more request.

        Ma Foi Academy has been very generous with its premises so far, 
giving us free access for both GLV and Chennai.rb sessions (thanks to 
Asokan). Alas, things have changed, and all good things must come to an 
end. Academy has indicated its inability to let us use the premises 
anymore, so I have to scout for a new host now. Though I initially 
thought of IITM, I would prefer a more central location so that it is 
accessible to all of us.

        I would love it if any software companies, colleges come forward 
to provide a meeting place for the Chennai Ruby Brigade. What we would 
need is simple: a hall with 20-30 seater capacity with projector so that 
the speaker can hook up his laptop to, and internet access would be just 
great, if it can be arranged.  Please speak to your bosses, if they're 
the progressive types ;-)

        So what do you get in return? Free knowledge. You get to hear 
cutting-edge topics on Ruby, Ruby on Rails, how to develop, run and host 
it, new stuff, etc. There are plans to invite speakers from other Ruby 
user groups across the country (I have at least one speaker lined up).

        Not just Ruby, we have plans to discuss up and coming languages 
like Haskell, Lua, Io, etc. Suffice it to say that you will get to hear 
some very interesting technical topics for no cost at all. Plus, you 
will always have the community's good will. I hope that didn't sound 
like some elevator pitch, I really believe that you will get a great 
benefit out of letting us use your premises. In case you are interested, 
please write back to me (on the 'from' id of this mail).

TIA,
Vamsee.

Hi Jeya Ram,

--- "Jeya Ram.P" <apjram@yahoo.com> wrote:
>  How can we open the Microsoft Visio .vsd files in
> SUSE linux. 

That's the problem with closed source proprietary
formats. They are not open standards and they won't
support working on different environments.

You can try it with wine, but, I'd definitely
recommend moving to dia or kivio:

Dia:
http://www.gnome.org/projects/dia/

Kivio:
http://www.thekompany.com/projects/kivio/

**** brief info re SPIN
"SPIN, Chennai (Software Process Improvement Network) is a forum of Software
Professionals for open exchange of software process improvement experiences
and ideas. The organization serves as a source of educational, scientific
and practical information for its members, other SPIN organizations, and the
general software community. The SPIN Group aims to be a leadership forum for
open exchange of SPI experiences and ideas, covering all aspects of how an
organization improves the way it develops and maintains software and
delivers software intensive services. SPIN organizes a variety of meetings,
all aimed at mutual self-help for practitioners.

SPIN Chennai was formed as early as 1994 and was one of the earliest SPIN
chapters in India. It has been functioning as a voluntary body of Software
professionals since then."
for more info:  http://www.spinchennai.org/spin_aboutus.asp

I hope you realize that it is possible to restrict your javascript
from doing all that in Firefox (and I think in 1.5, these restrictions
are on by default). Look at Tools->Options->Content->Enable
Javascript->Advanced.

Binand

Greetings!

The OS Group of Technische Universit?t Dresden
(TUD:OS) has released a live demo CD of their
operating system project. 

Some highlights of the Demo CD include a new approach
for securing graphical user interfaces called
Nitpicker, multiple L4Linux kernels running at the
same time on top of a L4/Fiasco, a survey on our reuse
of device drivers on the TUD:OS platform, native
Qt-applications, the DOpE windowing system and a
prototype of a secure E-commerce application based on
TUD:OS.

More information, an ISO image, and screenshots are
available at the demo CD website:

   http://demo.tudos.org

From siva.ilugc at gmail.com  Tue Mar 14 21:44:24 2006
From: siva.ilugc at gmail.com (Sivasankar Chander)
Date: Tue Mar 14 21:44:33 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Ekiga [Was: GnomeMeeting: unable to txmit]
Message-ID: <a8f990120603140814y608c766cq6038a29ff7ec26e4@mail.gmail.com>

Folks,
        The Ekiga VoIP client has been released - this is the
successor to GnomeMeeting, by the same team:

http://linux.slashdot.org/linux/06/03/13/1658206.shtml

They're also providing free SIP accounts at ekiga.net, so go
there and pick up your account now. Mine is:

sip:siva@ekiga.net

However, I haven't got my box fully configured to make calls
yet - in principle, it should be possible to do all 3 of:

1) PC-to-PC SIP calls;
2) PC-to-phone SIP calls;
3) phone-to-PC SIP calls.

and in all cases it should work for international calls as well.
It also has support for associating your SIP account with
a real phone number, so you can give people only your real
phone number, and receive SIP calls at the PC.

I'm configuring a machine for this now, but it may take a
while to get it going. I've resolved all the dependencies,
but the Ekiga build itself breaks in the final stages due
to some issue with scrollkeeper - I'll give the details
in another posting. If anybody beats me to it, please
post a mini-HOWTO.

-Siva

>         The Ekiga VoIP client has been released - this is the
> successor to GnomeMeeting, by the same team:
>
> http://linux.slashdot.org/linux/06/03/13/1658206.shtml
>
> They're also providing free SIP accounts at ekiga.net, so go
> there and pick up your account now. Mine is:
>
> sip:siva@ekiga.net
>
> However, I haven't got my box fully configured to make calls
> yet - in principle, it should be possible to do all 3 of:
>
> 1) PC-to-PC SIP calls;
> 2) PC-to-phone SIP calls;
> 3) phone-to-PC SIP calls.
>
> and in all cases it should work for international calls as well.
> It also has support for associating your SIP account with
> a real phone number, so you can give people only your real
> phone number, and receive SIP calls at the PC.
>
> I'm configuring a machine for this now, but it may take a
> while to get it going. I've resolved all the dependencies,
> but the Ekiga build itself breaks in the final stages due
> to some issue with scrollkeeper - I'll give the details
> in another posting. If anybody beats me to it, please
> post a mini-HOWTO.

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Tue Mar 14 22:19:06 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Wed Mar 15 11:49:23 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Help with UI
In-Reply-To: <4417AE78.000003.01764@HOME-WPN8N6WLXQ>
Message-ID: <20060315061906.89836.qmail@web50214.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

--- Bharath Narayan M G <bharath144@gmail.com> wrote:
> We are trying to develop a UI for some application.
> I would like to know
> what tool I should use to develop it. We have
> thought of using GTK. 

GTK is written in C. So, if you are comfortable with
C, you can use glade for the UI design.

http://glade.gnome.org/

If you are comfortable with C++ you can try Qt.
KDevelop can be used as an IDE along with Qt designer
for front-end design.

http://women.kde.org/articles/tutorials/kdevelop3/

You can also use Motif libraries and Lesstif for GUI
development on GNU/Linux.

http://www.opengroup.org/openmotif/

http://www.lesstif.org/

Have fun,

SK

On 3/15/06, Bharath Narayan M G <bharath144@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> Hello all,
> We are trying to develop a UI for some application. I would like to know
> what tool I should use to develop it. We have thought of using GTK. We
> want
> it to look something like thunderbird (I mean the UI). If I am wrong any

>
If it is an application that will be accessed over the network then I would
suggest a browser based AJAX client. It can do whatever a thick client can
do but with none of the hassles of deployment. And if at all you want to
deploy the same application over a mobile device (in these times of 3G and
mobile WiFi this will become a necessity soon) then it is only an xslt away.

regds,
mano

Hi bharath,
 i think u got some idea from previous replay. Well i had a same problem 
also. I started with GTK+ but later i switched to Qt for fast 
development and multiplatform support.

This feasibilty study showed me that if u are strong in c and love to 
code extensively then go for GTK+.If u are realy building mail client 
based on gtk+ then u can download lightweight mailclient  sylpheed... 
(http://sylpheed.good-day.net/en/) see the source code..it is based on GTK+

but u have to have proper understanding of large C code. It is time being.

If u want to do with small time , then my recomendation is for Qt( 
support muliplatform(win,linux,mac,etc..)less coding,C++ based,easy to 
learn). It comes with very good Documentation from Trolltech. It will 
help u too much.

I would not suggest motif( it is old and not so look and feel)..

"If it is an application that will be accessed over the network then I would suggest a browser based AJAX client."...

i would suggest to look this link

http://www.roundcube.net/

Have a fun!

On 3/15/06, Toufeeq Hussain <toufeeqh@gmail.com> wrote:
>
>
> Would a build system like jhbuild or garnome help ?
> GNOME 2.14 ships with Ekiga(I guess), so the dependency part will be
> taken care of by the build system.


Hi Toufeeq,
                 The build breakage seems to be Fedora-specific, and
related to issues with libtool and libxml2 - I'm planning to bypass
some of the issues with pre-built binary RPMs and then attempt
to build it again. Part of the problems are due to my configuration -
it started as a RH 7.3 box and has been upgraded over the years
to somewhere between FC3 and FC4.

YMMV, but the following set of packages had to be rebuilt and
installed on my box to resolve dependencies:

Pyrex-0.9.3-2
cups-1.1.23-15.4
libgnomecups-0.2.0-2
dbus-0.33-3.fc4.1
bind-9.3.1-14_FC4
(all of the above required for => openldap-2.2.29-1)
gnome-doc-utils-0.5.7-1   (from fedora development)
pwlib-1.10.0-1 (from ekiga.net)
opal-2.2.0-1 (from ekiga.net)
libavc1394-0.4.1-8 (from FC4)

At this point, all the dependencies are resolved, and I can
*almost* build ekiga-2.0.0-1 from SRPM, but the build breaks
near the end with something related to var/lib/scrollkeeper.
I'll look at it later - it appears that ekiga needs to be built
as root, or scrollkeeper needs an update. Attempts to rebuild
more recent versions of scrollkeeper break on lubxml2/libtool
suckage.

-Siva

I have installed Ekiga 2.0.1 successfully in Ubuntu Breezy (5.10). I built
it from source downloaded from http://ekiga.org. I had to download

monodoc while installing avahi since backport is not available for latest
version of monodoc). All other dependencied were met by the ubuntu
repositories.

I resolved it by building ekiga-2.0.0-1 as root (I dislike doing
this, but it was the easiest way out), with scrollkeeper-0.3.14-5.
It built and installed cleanly, and I was able to start it and
go through the initial configuration. Most of what I said
earlier should apply to FC3/FC4 boxes. I'll probably dedicate
an old P2/P3 box with a soundcard running a minimal FC4
installation as an Ekiga SIP phone, later - I've got a HP
Vectra that fits the bill perfectly.

Some interesting combinations of Asterix servers with Ekiga
clients should be possible - budding entrepreneurs who want
to get into VoIP should take note. This is a highly disruptive
technology, if coupled with Mesh Wi-Fi networks.

-Siva

If ease of deployment is a concern then browser based applications are the
best.

Found a bug in the UI logic? Just fix it in your server. No sweat. You dont
have to contact every user of your app and tell him to upgrade his version.

Introduced a new feature which you find cool? Just mark it 'New' and it is
delivered soon as a user logs in. No download-patch cycle for the user - to
try a feature she might find dumb and be pissed off for having gone to all
the trouble!

All this plus the access from the mobile phone - india's PC!

mano

Sorry. Thought I'll add some more (borrowed) insights:

When you give a browser based UI you are delivering a service - which is
what the client is actually interested in. In thick clients the stress,
unwittingly, seems to be on the software. The service seems to follow it in
importance!

You can deliver a new feature everyday and have a high chance of your users
trying many of them. Like google does. In thickclient deployment mode you
can realistically give a bunched up set of features (actually _software_
that has some features), maybe once a month. And many of those features will
go undiscovered. Like what Microsoft does.
--
All generalizations are false.

Hi KaruppuSwamy,

--- KaruppuSwamy T <karuppuswamy@gmail.com> wrote:
> How Linux kernel supports this?

There are a number of distros that you can use for
64-bit processing.

The following is for laptops, but, will give you an
idea on the distros that are available for 64-bit:

http://tuxmobil.org/cpu_64bit.html

> When there is not much 64 bit applications
> available, will it be worth?

Who said so? Most 64-bit distros ship with 64-bit
compiled applications. There are some that are
compiled with 32-bit.

Its just that when you are using 32-bit applications
you are not using the processor to its full, but, it
is always backward compatible.

You would probably find 64-bit useful if you are
running servers, gaming, clusters, rendering
(blender), synthesis (VLSI) etc.

> 64-bit processors/Dual-Core and Motherboards
> (Original Intel) available in
> Chennai, now?

I think Sudharshan was planning to buy and run AMD
64-bit? Not sure. 

https://alioth.debian.org/docman/view.php/30192/21/debian-amd64-howto.html

Have fun,

SK

and open standards. HTML is an open protocol. M$ has many closed 
protocols and standards that are exposed to developers under NDA.

or less come under the foss umbrella.

Subject: [Ilugc] Latest Hardware compatibility for Linux
In-Reply-To: <1142597559.8846.1.camel@localhost.localdomain>

Message-ID: <5d0d0e310603170958i2027a935p4640115756209915@mail.gmail.com>

On 3/17/06, Sudharshan S <sudharsh@gmail.com> wrote:
> I guess you are an experienced linux user..
> go the debian way, package management is easy,
> else there are certain distros for the 64bit archs.

Mixing 32bit and 64bit apps are handled differently in various distros.
Debian/Ubuntu just don't allow this mixing, so if you are installing the
64 bit version of a distron and a 64 bit version of a particular application
is not available, then you have to setup a minimalistic chroot environment
with the required 32 bit libraries. Gentoo, IRC, handle this in a different
way by placing 64 bit libraries in /lib64/ so that 32bit and 64bit of the same
library can coexist.

As a side note: I just saw a flashy new intel dual core MAC and spell bound
by the awesome desing and specification. There were words around that
the box was able to boot gentoo.

--
Warm Regards,
Vijairaj
