From ashokgautham at gmail.com  Sat Mar 18 12:44:05 2006
From: ashokgautham at gmail.com (Ashok Gautham J.)
Date: Sat Mar 18 12:44:17 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Simple linux playlist.
Message-ID: <5580629a0603172314h3a55d599qde51146ff34e6315@mail.gmail.com>

Linux has taught me many lessons. More precisely, its pioneer Linus
Torvalds. One of the lessons is this:

*When you don't have some software or a necessity, dont wait for others to.
do it yourself like Linus did.*


 It may take some time but the satisfaction you get is immense. I wanted a
play list for Realplayer10. But did not find it. I like to put on some 20
songs and then work maths for my exams. ( a habit from the time i was using
Windows. So I had to select each song when the previous was played( I hated
it, it was a hindrance ). I decided to write a play list software and was
pleasantly surprised what a few command and a simple cpp program could do.
True to Linux culture i share my finding for noobs like me.

Most people have all their songs (or most) in a single folder. Do this:

* Open a terminal window and type

*ls folder name > songlist.txt*

* Then open a file called listtoplaylist.cpp and type the following code .

   *#include <string>*

            *#include <fstream>*

            *using namespace std;*

            *int main() {*

            *ifstream in("songlist.txt"); // Open for reading*

            *ofstream out("playlist.sh"); // Open for writing*

            *string s;*

            *while(getline(in, s)) // Discards newline char*

            * out <<"#realplay -q" <<" \'Foldername\'" <<"\'"<<
            s <<"\'" <<"\n"; }*

            */*prints #realplay -q 'Foldername' 'filename' in
            play list.sh*/*

         */*I use ' and ' because the filename and foldername can
         have spaces*/*

* Save it and in the terminal window type

   *g++ -o listtoplaylist listtoplaylist.cpp*


 * This creates a file called playlist.sh . Then create a folder called
Backuplist and copy the file playlist.sh to the folder.


*Then open a file called refresh.sh and in it type:

*rm playlist.sh*

* cp Backuplist/playlist.sh <name_of_folder_of_original_playlist>*


 * Finally create another file in the same folder as the original playlist
called update.sh and then in it type:

   *rm Backuplist/playlist.sh*

   *cp playlist.sh Backuplist*


 Now this is how it works.

Uncomment(remove the #sign ) of all the lines containing songs you want to
play.

Then execute playlist.sh by typing in the terminal* *after navigating to the
folder.

*./playlist.sh*

* *I created the backup file with a reason, You need not take care to put
the # back for every line once the playlist is comleted. You can just type
in the terminal

*./refresh.sh*

But at the same time you can keep the original playlist as it is too by not
refreshing.

 You can also add new songs to the playlist by typing #realplay -q
'<songname with path>' in the original playlist file. Then save the playlist
file. But be sure to do a *./refresh.sh *before adding new names to ensure
that all lines are commented out in the playlist. Then add names and save
it( with # preceding them).

Then type

*./update.sh.*

This will make sure that your backup list is up to date.

Notes:

   1.

         The -q option tells the player to close once playback is
         over. this ensures that the next line in the script,
         playlist.sh, (ie. the next song) will be executed.
         2.

         real player10 can be downloaded from http://www.real.com
         3.

         You can manage stuff using just the playlist.sh file
         alone.But be sure to put the # back in all lines u
         uncommented.
         4.

         I am planning to create a single cpp program that can
         handle all this. but i am searching for a command to execute
a shell command
         inside a cpp program. If you know the command(something like
exec in python)
         tell me.
         5.

         You can also use it with other players by replacing
         "realplay -q"with the shell command for the player with a
relevent option.
         6.

         The single quotes are to make the computer understand it
         is a single file or folder if spaces are there in the file
name. Most of
         mine did.
         7.

         Create your own small codes and share it with the
         community to promote open source software.
         8.

         This may be a childplay for some gurus here. But I am
         doing it for the rest :) .
         9.

         Please send in your feedbacks and whether it works or not.
         It did for me.

In-Reply-To: <4cba61b90603172115h5f81e1e8ja8896678c7678c3f@mail.gmail.com>

Hi,

--- Gopalarathnam Venkatesan <gopal@gopalarathnam.com>
wrote:
> I think he's talking about GNU/Linux based on either
> SYSV / BSD flavor.

GNU/Linux uses the Linux kernel.

BSD distros use the BSD Unix kernel. 

They are both different, don't confuse, mix and match
them.

GNU/Linux distros are Red Hat, Fedora Core, Gentoo,
Debian, Ubuntu, Slackware et. al.

BSD distros are FreeBSD, OpenBSD, and NetBSD.

You can run Gnome on both GNU/Linux and FreeBSD, they
are all application packages ported to these
environments.

http://shearer.org/en/writing/whatarelinuxbsd.html

HTH,

SK

Greetings!

The photos taken during the "Introduction to FLOSS"
workshop at SSN College of Engineering, SSN Nagar,
Tamil Nadu, India, today, Saturday, March 18, 2006 can
be viewed from:

http://www.shakthimaan.com/Mambo/gallery/album25

Thanks to the Management, SSN College of Engineering,
Dr. Aravindhan (HOD, CSD), Prof. Balasubramanian
(Lecturer, CSD), and to students and faculty/staff of
SSN College of Engineering.

Thanks to Naren who has been coordinating this event
for the past three weeks.

* Vijay Kumar began the day's proceedings with
introduction to free software.

* I then conducted the "Careers with GNU/Linux"
presentation. It can be freely downloaded (under CC
and Share Alike license) from:

http://shakthimaan.com/downloads.html

* Joe Steeve handled installation of Fedora Core.

* We had lunch between 11:30 and 12:30.

* Ashwin began the afternoon session with his talk on
"Squid, GLAMP, ntop". His presentation (.pdf) (also
under CC and Share Alike license) can be downloaded
from:

http://www.shakthimaan.com/downloads/glv/presentations/ssn.ashwin.mar.18.2006.pdf
[362 KB]

http://www.shakthimaan.com/downloads/glv/presentations/ssn.ashwin.mar.18.2006.odp
[492 KB]

* Vijay then gave an introduction to GUI programming
with GTK.

* Sujith, from NRC-FOSS, followed, with his
presentation on Scilab and GNU Octave.

* I then gave a demo of "Multimedia on GNU/Linux" and
played the the demo video of xgl/opengl.

The audience were from different departments, and we
had good interactive sessions.

SSN folks are very keen on *nix environments, and are
interested in many follow-up sessions.

Suggestions were provided to start a user group within
campus so students can participate.

Thanks to Vijay Kumar, Joe Steeve, Naren, Ashwin,
Sujith for their company and participation. I had a
great time!

Subject: [Ilugc] Simple linux playlist.
In-Reply-To: <5580629a0603172314h3a55d599qde51146ff34e6315@mail.gmail.com>
References: <5580629a0603172314h3a55d599qde51146ff34e6315@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <200603182221.31765.trshash84@gmail.com>

On Saturday 18 March 2006 12:44, Ashok Gautham J. wrote:
> Linux has taught me many lessons. More precisely, its pioneer Linus
> Torvalds. One of the lessons is this:
>
> *When you don't have some software or a necessity, dont wait for others to.
> do it yourself like Linus did.*
>
>
>  It may take some time but the satisfaction you get is immense. I wanted a
> play list for Realplayer10. But did not find it. I like to put on some 20
> songs and then work maths for my exams. ( a habit from the time i was using
> Windows. So I had to select each song when the previous was played( I hated
> it, it was a hindrance ). I decided to write a play list software and was
> pleasantly surprised what a few command and a simple cpp program could do.
> True to Linux culture i share my finding for noobs like me.

It would be easier to use a scripting language for things like this. I 
personally use python for such tasks. Here's a script I wrote to split one 
huge HTML file into several small HTML files, where the each small file is 
delimited by a <h2> tag.

#!/usr/bin/env python

import os,sys

infile=open(sys.argv[1])
outdir=sys.argv[2]+'/'

instream=infile.read()
#os.mkdir(outdir)

filename_template=sys.argv[4]
file_template=open(sys.argv[3]).read()

ins=instream[instream.find("<body>")+6:instream.find("</body>")-1] # Get the 
actual body conten

chapters=dict()

i=0
st=0
end=0
while st <= len(ins):
    end=ins.find('<h1 align="center">')
    st=end
    text='<h1 align="center">'+ins[:end]
    ins=ins[end+len('<h1 align="center">'):]
    title=sys.argv[4]+" Chapter " + str(i)

    filename=filename_template+'-'+str(i)+'.html'
    if(i != 0):
        prev_filename=filename_template+'-'+str(i-1)+'.html'
    else:
        prev_filename=""
    next_filename=filename_template+'-'+str(i+1)+'.html'
    file_out=file_template.replace("$TEXT", text).replace("$TITLE", 
title).replace("$NEXT", next_filename).replace("$PREV", prev_filename)
    path=outdir+'/'+filename
    f=open(path, 'w')
    f.write(file_out)
    chapters[i]=filename
    f.close()
    i+=1

Though, tell me if mailing it messes up the formatting - leading whitespaces 
ARE significant in python

On 3/18/06, Shakthi Kannan <cyborg4k@yahoo.com> wrote:
>
> GNU/Linux uses the Linux kernel.
>
> BSD distros use the BSD Unix kernel.
>
> They are both different, don't confuse, mix and match
> them.

Excuse me, I was mentioning about the flavor of Unix as in BSD/SYSV
not about the kernel.
Slackware used to be a kind of BSD flavor housing the init scripts
under /etc/rc.d unlike the SYSV (/etc/rc?.d) until Slackware 7. 
Slackware 7 and after had SYSV compatibility.

The BSDs don't have runlevels unlike the SYSV based Unices.  SunOS was
a BSD flavor Unix until Sun decided (may be due to marketing strategy
or whatever I don't know) to make Solaris a SYSV like.

--
Gopalarathnam Venkatesan

heartily recommend the Airtel guys. Looks like it's a bit expensive than 
the others. I have a 999Rs plan @ 256kbps unlimited.

The service is amazing, I got an adsl router which I can connect through 
USB or eth, configuring was all done through the browser, and they'll do 
it for you. So, my Ubuntu-running thinkpad can happily connect to the 
net, the speed is decent, and there was only one occasion when the 
connection went down, and there was actually some technical person on 
the other side when I called them up at 5 am in the morning to lodge my 
complaint. I guess you get what  you pay for.

Ok, at the risk of sounding like some sales guy for Airtel, you also get 
a landline phone with the broadband connection, and you get 5% off the 
combined bill if you have an Airtel postpaid cell connection.

Dear all

On 18th March me,thyagu and baskar went to Arunai Engg college,
Tiruvannamalai.

There were about 50 student volunteers for the forthcoming linux
expo. In the forenoon session we exposed them to FOSS philosophy,
installation of Linux and some gui tools like Openoffice. In the
after noon we announced the list of topics under which the expo will
be held and asked students to volunteer. After this we went to lab,
interacted with each set of 3-4 volunteers. Explained them the basics
of those topics, guided them where the documents are available to
study.

>From the interaction, I feel we will be having highly enthusiastic
set of  student volunteers. They are willing to learn a lot. It is
now ILUGC responsibility to utilise this students pool.

The proposed stalls with volunteers so far opted are given below. We
need many more volunteers for the event. Kindly volunteer and ilugc
manaththa kappathunga.

The college admin and faculty are very good and take care of us well.
They look forward for a successful show. Atleast 10 colleges around
Tiruvannamalai have promised to visit the expo. The expection is
about 3000 visitors this time.

The FOSS Meet at NIT Calicut was a grand success. Thanks to Praveen, 
Amarjit.

The event started with a usual inaugration followed by Lectures on various 
topics like Gentoo, Ruby, FOSS Foundry, VLSI/EDA Tools, Embedded Linux, FOSS

curiosity to learn..

Ahh! Don't assign me to any stall. I'll keep moving

the visitors.

> Install of Linux & Careers with GNU/Linux: 11.00 - 
> 11.30   Shakthi & Raman

I will atleast need 30 minutes for "Careers with
GNU/Linux".

I'd appreciate if you can find time to play two
movies:

1. Revolution OS (85 minutes)
2. The.Code.Linux.avi (60 minutes)

Keeping the introductory talk to 15 minutes and
playing the movie will give them the big picture. A
picture is a thousand words!

> 8. Advanced Programming gcc,make etc  or Device 
> Driver programming  (Sakthi shall choose or cover 
> both)   15.30 - 16.00    Sakthi

For beginners, device driver programming will not make
any sense. I shall cover gcc, Makefiles, make.

A request to new speakers:

1. Please stick to the time. Most of them _never_
follow this.

If your slot is between time x and time y (x<y), stop
before time y. If you delay, all other's schedules
will get delayed. Or, we may have to find a way to get
you out in time y.

2. Never prepare a speech. Just jot down the
points/topics that you want to address.

3. Don't be monotonous in your speech. Use some voice
modulation.

4. Expect feedback from the audience. Make it
interactive.

5. Never put too much text in your slides. Keep text
to a minimal, and use large size  in your fonts. If
you can give as much demos or provide screenshots, the
audience will be interested.

Raman, please let me know if the changes can be
incorporated,

Thanks,

SK

> INFORMS THE USER that the
> device is safe to use now.

3. See (2) above.

> Yoper needs to achive a similar kinda device
> handling wherein when an USB
> device is attached, create the node in /dev/usb(x) x
> being the kernel-number
> and inform the user that a device is attached prior
> to putting an icon in
> the desktop.

I already told you once. I will tell it you once again
nicely.

udevd runs in user-space, detects USB device
filesystem, mounts it and creates an icon on your
desktop with the mount point. 

All recent distros do this for you.
 
> i am confused here whether to target HAL or DBUS or
> Hotplu or udev!

D+ and D- are USB bus data lines.

udevfs is udev filesystem support in kernel space.

hotplug support should be enabled in the kernel.

Look at HAL and udev.

From karuppuswamy at gmail.com  Mon Mar 20 15:12:51 2006
From: karuppuswamy at gmail.com (KaruppuSwamy T)
Date: Mon Mar 20 15:13:02 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Regarding udev and usb
In-Reply-To: <a54a308e0603191026l7c01e5a4pba1954727d04085f@mail.gmail.com>
References: <a54a308e0603181234u715f664am12ca01f8b5d694b7@mail.gmail.com>
	<a54a308e0603191026l7c01e5a4pba1954727d04085f@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <a1da1e5e0603200142s7e48eda0w67ee58cb91599278@mail.gmail.com>

>
>
> To make this happen, should i write a udev rule or handle through
> Hotplug?.
>

Here is a FAQ in
http://www.kernel.org/pub/linux/utils/kernel/hotplug/udev-FAQ.

Q: Can I use udev to automount a USB device when I connect it?
A: Technically, yes, but udev is not intended for this. All major distributions
   use HAL (http://freedesktop.org/wiki/Software_2fhal) for this, which also
   watches devices with removable media and integrates into the
desktop software.

As per this, I think it is better to use HAL for your task. HAL and
D-BUS combined together will serve the purpose very well.
More info: http://linux-hotplug.sourceforge.net/ and
http://dbus.freedesktop.org/doc/dbus-tutorial.html

Regards
T.KaruppuSwamy

> A request to new speakers:
>
> 1. Please stick to the time. Most of them _never_
> follow this.
>
> If your slot is between time x and time y (x<y), stop
> before time y. If you delay, all other's schedules
> will get delayed. Or, we may have to find a way to get
> you out in time y.
>
> 2. Never prepare a speech. Just jot down the
> points/topics that you want to address.
>
> 3. Don't be monotonous in your speech. Use some voice
> modulation.
>

> you can give as much demos or provide screenshots, the
> audience will be interested.

Subject: [Ilugc] How to modify password strength in RHEL

Message-ID: <d2a92d610603200553x423e159bq@mail.gmail.com>

On 20/03/06, R.Subramanian (RS) <rs2003@gmail.com> wrote:
> > Anyway, edit /etc/login.defs and change PASS_MIN_LEN to whatever you want.
>
> I have tried. It is not working in rhel

You have got me interested. And guess what - /etc/login.defs is
deprecated. Here is what I have found:

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=17487

This minimum length option is to be specified in
/etc/pam.d/system-auth (and it is more complicated than what we
thought it was). To change the minimum length requirement to 4
characters, what you need to do is to have:

password  required pam_cracklib.so dcredit=0 ucredit=0 ocredit=0
lcredit=0 minlen=4

Read the full bug content - it is very illuminating.

Binand

Binand

> Message: 6
> Date: Mon, 20 Mar 2006 15:12:51 +0530
> From: "KaruppuSwamy T" <karuppuswamy@gmail.com>
> Subject: Re: [Ilugc] Regarding udev and usb
> To: "Chennai Linux User's Group Group" <ilugc@ae.iitm.ac.in>
> Message-ID:
>        <a1da1e5e0603200142s7e48eda0w67ee58cb91599278@mail.gmail.com>
> Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
>
> >
> >
> > To make this happen, should i write a udev rule or handle through
> > Hotplug?.
> >
>
> Here is a FAQ in
> http://www.kernel.org/pub/linux/utils/kernel/hotplug/udev-FAQ.
>
> Q: Can I use udev to automount a USB device when I connect it?
> A: Technically, yes, but udev is not intended for this. All major
> distributions
>   use HAL (http://freedesktop.org/wiki/Software_2fhal) for this, which
> also
>   watches devices with removable media and integrates into the
> desktop software.
>
> As per this, I think it is better to use HAL for your task. HAL and
> D-BUS combined together will serve the purpose very well.
> More info: http://linux-hotplug.sourceforge.net/ and
> http://dbus.freedesktop.org/doc/dbus-tutorial.html
>
> Regards
> T.KaruppuSwamy
>

> Q: Can I use udev to automount a USB device when I connect it?
> A: Technically, yes, but udev is not intended for this. All major
> distributions
>    use HAL (http://freedesktop.org/wiki/Software_2fhal) for this, which
> also
>    watches devices with removable media and integrates into the
> desktop software.
>

> D-BUS combined together will serve the purpose very well.
> More info: http://linux-hotplug.sourceforge.net/ and
> http://dbus.freedesktop.org/doc/dbus-tutorial.html

The ometer hardware abstraction document was written by Havoc Pennington 
and David Zeuthen (both from Red Hat ) wrote the hardware abstraction 
library based on the same idea and specification. So the thing you are 
looking for already exists and is being widely used in the form of HAL.  
If you need more details on HAL, ask in the project mailing list.

Subject: [Ilugc] Unable to connet CVS from remote system
In-Reply-To: <3AEC1E10243A314391FE9C01CD65429B37FCF1@mail.esn.co.in>

On 3/21/06, Mukund JB. <mukundjb@esntechnologies.co.in> wrote:
>
> # cvs commit first_cvs
>
> (A file open with some related and info and when I close it I find)
>
> Log message unchanged or not specified
>
> a)bort c)ontonue e)dit !)reuse this message unchanged for remaining dirs
>
> Action: (continue) c
>
> cvs [server aborted]: 'root' is not allowed to commit files
>
>
>
> What am I doing wrong in this?
>
> Any ideas?
>

The message says it all root user is not allowed to make any commit in
CVS by default. Below is what I find as a explanation...

'root' is not allowed to commit files
    When committing a permanent change, CVS makes a log entry of who
committed the change. If you are committing the change logged in as
"root" (not under "su" or other root-priv giving program), CVS cannot
determine who is actually making the change. As such, by default, CVS
disallows changes to be committed by users logged in as "root". (You
can disable this option by commenting out the definition of
CVS_BADROOT in `options.h' before building CVS.


Try commit with other normal user. Note that user needs write
permission on $CVSROOT directory.

--
Cheers,
Sivam

Hi,

1. Ensure that your firmware is loaded properly.

2. You can try disabling IPV6 by editing /etc/modules.conf. Comment and
uncomment as shown below:

#alias net-pf-10 ipv6
alias net-pf-10 off

Regards
T.KaruppuSwamy

From toufeeqh at gmail.com  Wed Mar 22 14:47:26 2006

Subject: [Ilugc] [OT] Help the blowfish to keep swimming!

Hi,

Been planning to do this for a long time, finally did it today.
If you follow OpenBSD, all their development happens in Hackathon's
held mostly in Canada,for this they fly in people from around the
world and get them together under one roof and hack away at
code..either OpenBSD or OpenSSH or any part of the OpenBSD subsystem
which requires attention.

One such hackathon: http://kerneltrap.org/node/5186

Something happened in 2003,Theo went ahead and made anti-Iraq remarks
and DARPA cut off their funds.
http://www.computerworld.com/securitytopics/security/story/0,10801,80473,00.html

Today OpenBSD needs funds to continue the hackathon-culture.The CD
sales have dried up and as people prefer to use the FTP mirrors
instead.The project's "press" release:
http://undeadly.org/cgi?action=article&sid=20060321034114

So I ordered a tee-shirt from OpenBSD.org

Here it is: http://openbsd.org/tshirts.html#9

Costs $25 + shipping but worth it,and it's for a good cause.

It's a not a big amount and OpenBSD CD's are worthless to me(for now )
and I'm not an IT manager to donate money but the tee is a small way
of saying Thank You for their work on OpenSSH which basically makes my
life complete. :)

-Toufeeq
--
blog @ http://toufeeq.blogspot.com

Using Apache's htpasswd command to manipulate the $CVSROOT/passwd file
is the preferred way. Check other things that might cause the error.

Message-ID: <3AEC1E10243A314391FE9C01CD65429B37FDC4@mail.esn.co.in>

Dear Linux Team,

 

I am trying to understand the USB Architecture and write my own client
driver under Linux and some mew concepts of 2.6.x.

 

My point of about kref

----------------------

Used when the multiple threads are involved within the driver.

I am not sure whether this can be when there are no thread within the
driver and to control the Process synchronization. Can I get some
clarity on this?

 

Main Question

-------------

I have seen that kref_init () is issues in probe.     // no issue with
this

 

Device memory allocation and Kref_get() call are issued in open context.
Fine.ok.

 

In that case kref_put should be called in close context or any error
context. Right?

Yes, I find these two being issued in the usb-skeleton driver.

 

But, I find additional kref_put() call in disconnect? That too without
any condition checking? Why do I need it here?

 

Regards,

Mukund Jampala

Hi,
>  Mobole : LG 1530 CDMA - Reliance Connection
>  Laptop : Acer -  Linux Novell Desktop 9.3

You hav to edit files called wvdial.conf and resolv.conf.
resolv.conf should contain the nameserver or whatever with which you
resolv the connection with ur isp.
The chaps at support centre will provide you with that one..

You could also use gnome-ppp or kppp (but u need to enter the
nameservers though)

Just remember that you dial to #777 for cdma phones and default
Initialization string should be changed to AT+CRM=1..and you are
rocking. Play around the GUI for that


regards
Sudharshan S

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Wed Mar 22 07:15:12 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Wed Mar 22 20:45:19 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] USB-skeleton & kref query
In-Reply-To: <3AEC1E10243A314391FE9C01CD65429B37FDC4@mail.esn.co.in>
Message-ID: <20060322151512.98239.qmail@web50214.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi Mukund and others,

--- "Mukund JB." <mukundjb@esntechnologies.co.in>
wrote:
> My point of about kref
> 
> ----------------------
> 
> Used when the multiple threads are involved within
> the driver.
> 
> I am not sure whether this can be when there are no
> thread within the
> driver and to control the Process synchronization.

Code should always be such that it will work when
multiple processes/threads are involved.

> Can I get some
> clarity on this?

In 2.6 kernels:

struct kref {
 atomic_t refcount;
}

Source:
http://lxr.linux.no/source/include/linux/kref.h#L23
 
In 2.4 kernels:

static __inline__ void atomic_inc(volatile atomic_t
*v)
{
  unsigned long flags;
 
  __save_flags_cli(flags);
  v->counter += 1;
  __restore_flags(flags);
}

Source:
http://lxr.linux.no/source/include/asm-arm/atomic.h?v=2.4.20#L53

> In that case kref_put should be called in close
> context or any error
> context. Right?
> 
> Yes, I find these two being issued in the
> usb-skeleton driver.
 
... and also extensively in 2.6 device drivers when
they bring in kobjects, ksets, and ksubsystems.  
 
> But, I find additional kref_put() call in
> disconnect? That too without
> any condition checking? Why do I need it here?

In 2.4 kernels, to allocate resources to processes,
and to know how many are using it you will use the
following functions: atomic_inc(), atomic_dec() et.
al.

Similarily in 2.6 kernels, with the integration of the
new device class model, you will be using kref_get(),
kref_put() et. al.

Source: http://lxr.linux.no/source/lib/kref.c#L30

I'd definitely recommend that you read "Chapter 14:
The Linux Device Model" from Linux Device Drivers by
Alessandro Rubini and Jonathan Corbett.

http://lwn.net/Kernel/LDD3/

HTH,

SK

-------- Original Message --------
Subject: 	[GNU/FSF Press] Press Release: GPL tested in US courts in Wallace
Date: 	Wed, 22 Mar 2006 19:52:39 -0500
From: 	Peter Brown <peterb@fsf.org>
To: 	info-press@gnu.org



The GPL tested in US courts - Wallace Vs FSF.

The GNU General Public License stands firm.

On Monday March 20, 2006 US Federal Judge John Daniel Tinder, dismissed
the Sherman Act antitrust claims brought against the Free Software
Foundation. The claims made by Plaintiff Daniel Wallace included: that
the General Public License (GPL) constituted a contract, combination or
conspiracy; that it created an unreasonable restraint of trade; and that
the FSF conspired with IBM, Red Hat Inc., Novell and other individuals
to pool and cross-license their copyrighted intellectual property in a
predatory price fixing scheme.

Peter Brown, FSF Executive Director, responded to the news, "As the
author of the GPL and copyright holder on the largest body of GPL'd
covered free software, the FSF hears many theories of potential legal
claims and challenges to the GPL. We hear the fear, uncertainty and
doubt (FUD) expressed, that the GPL has never been tested in court, and
that somehow that is a sign of its weakness. Nothing could be further
from the truth of course. Put quite simply, if you don't accept the
terms of the GPL, then you have no rights to the copyrighted works it
covers. What is there left to test? The GPL is a software license, it is
not a contract. It gives permissions from the copyright holder. You
don't want to accept those permissions? End of discussion."

On Monday, a US Federal Court Judge dismissed Daniel Wallace's case
saying "[The GPL] acts as a means by which certain software may be
copied, modified and redistributed without violating the software's
copyright protection. As such, the GPL encourages, rather than
discourages, free competition and the distribution of computer operating
systems, the benefits of which directly pass to consumers. These
benefits include lower prices, better access and more innovation."

Brown continued, "Let us all stop and consider the consequences of what
this US Federal Judge has said. On being presented with the facts
surrounding the GPL, he was able to define a range of benefits available
to those that value the freedoms delivered by the GPL. The question we
are all left with is, why would anyone put up with the inferred
consequences of proprietary software?", and, "If you care about lower
prices, better access to software, or more innovation, then GPL'd
software is for you. Or as the Free Software would describe that, you
value freedom".

Having dismissed the case, and finding in favor of the FSF and against
Wallace. The Judge also allowed FSF costs against Wallace. Wallace, now
has thirty days to appeal the decision, but the FSF expects no relevant
news on this matter.

--
About the Free Software Foundation
The Free Software Foundation, founded in 1985, is dedicated to promoting
computer users' right to use, study, copy, modify, and redistribute
computer programs. The FSF promotes the development and use of free (as
in freedom) software - particularly the GNU operating system and its
GNU/Linux variants - and free documentation for free software. The FSF
also helps to spread awareness of the ethical and political issues of
freedom in the use of software. Their Web site, located at www.fsf.org ,
is an important source of information about GNU/Linux. Donations to
support their work can be made at http://donate.fsf.org. Their
headquarters are in Boston, MA, USA.

Subject: [Ilugc] Regarding udev and usb
In-Reply-To: <a54a308e0603220508m72adf05cn5aadbd0b3ac40596@mail.gmail.com>
References: <a54a308e0603192142h63bf98aagf14f8054823576bf@mail.gmail.com>
	<20060320060550.58049.qmail@web50210.mail.yahoo.com>
	<a54a308e0603192224j3fe83f64j6e26d04450859249@mail.gmail.com>
	<48bd74c50603211204jf6026abxff6d9034e66edc64@mail.gmail.com>
	<a54a308e0603220508m72adf05cn5aadbd0b3ac40596@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <a54a308e0603221925h3877dacbu5e8844a6dafe28e2@mail.gmail.com>

Hi all,

Atlast after series of attempts and getting to know how udev manages and
what HAL is ,i was able to get notified when my usb thumbdrive got plugged
in :).

UDEV
======

It is done with udev. What happens when you plug in an device?. The kernel
identifies it as usb device, the bus name corresponds to "usb" and the
kernel action that is taking place is "add" this new device by loading the
appropiate modules.So here, the kernel sends the "add" message to the udev
to get the device node created.The udev creates it.

Now how to get the kernel message "add" and perform what we need?

Here comes into picture, the "udev rules". The udev has rules in the
/etc/udev/rules.d directory where each rule will be executed in a lexical
order when udev starts.The extension of a rule file is .rules. So i created
10-chaks.rules and added the following,

BUS=="usb", ACTION=="add", NAME="usb%n", RUN+="/usr/bin/mount-usb.sh usb%n"

I think the rule is self explanatory.

1) Check for bus usb
2) Check for action add
3) Apply the name usb%n than sda or sdb
4) Run the program given along with other programs which will run for this
device
5) For further queries, just see man udev - they are very clear and
documented good.

This is one way you can capture the device "add" from the kernel when it
passes to udev.

I even got links where it had written that udev is going to replace hotplug
fully and this article http://lwn.net/Articles/156027/ tells that ubuntu is
replacing hotplug with udev and also Yoper is moving forward with this
approach.

HAL
====

So what is HAL?

Here is a good info on HAL -->
http://www.redhat.com/magazine/003jan05/features/hal/

I understood HAL to be a separate layer with which desktop applications can
interact and get to know what the kernel is doing with the devices, whether
the device is getting detected or added or removed.The gnome-volume-manager
implements this but still is development stage.There is also an application
called KDE-HAL-Device-Manager which is a gui app for the program
"lshal".Type "lshal" in your shell and see the devices identified and
attached for your system.

HAL is able to do this with the interaction with dbus and kernel.The dbus
first gets informed and has the information on what device it is(usb or scsi
or pci etc.,).dbus python bindings are available to program.

So using HAL and an application program , you can capture USB add or
removal.But this requires the knowledge of dbus python programming.The dbus
source has examples on how to program in python.

Road to Success
==============

This is my first initial step which i thought i should share with ilugc.

The above udev example works for only usb thumbdrives having only one
partition(/dev/sda).It doesnt work for USB Mass Storage Devices where you
have more than one partition(/dev/sda1,/dev/sda2 etc.,).Need to dig around a
bit deeper for this.

Also, need to know what is the message relevant to when a CD ROM is inserted
and how it gets to know that it is Audio or Video or Blank CD or
DVD.gnome-volume-manager handles this also.

My longterm goal is to create a hal daemon monitoring for these services and
perform the necessary actions.

I dont want to use gnome-volume-manager as it is also in the development
stages and since there are not so many applications available in this area,
i have planned to write an application.

Friends who are very eager to help, can join me in this and you need not run
Yoper for this as dbus,udev,hal are common in every linux distribution
except for their rules :).

If this seems to be a mail where it violates ilugc policies and imitates W$
as shakthi said, am sorry, THIS IS A FEATURE OF LINUX KERNEL IMPLEMENTED AND
I WANT IT TO BE ENHANCED WITH GOOD SUPPORT AND APPLICATIONS FOR THIS
FEATURE.

Thanks for patiently reading my mail....will update as and when i progress
further....

From vamlists at gmx.net  Thu Mar 23 11:12:57 2006
From: vamlists at gmx.net (Vamsee Kanakala)
Date: Thu Mar 23 11:13:16 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] About Ruby
In-Reply-To: <4421166A.50001@gmail.com>
References: <4421166A.50001@gmail.com>
Message-ID: <44223561.9050203@gmx.net>

Prasanna Kumar wrote:

> how far ruby is used in developing real time aplications?
> where do we get that? if so  

Not much, if you ask me. For that matter, dynamic languages like Python 
and Ruby would be not-so-ideal choices for doing real time apps. 
Especially, since there is the extra burden of managing lots of dynamism 
(typing-related) and memory management with GC etc, performance would be 
pretty poor. Lots of resource-intensive parts of Ruby apps (like 
Mongrel, the webserver) are still written as C modules.

Of course, you wouldn't need to do much of that for regular apps, but 
Real-Time apps are a completely different game. I don't know much about 
RT stuff, maybe somebody else can explain about the languages ideal for 
this kind of apps.

> is there any ide for Ruby scripting language ?

Lots of them. There's RDT (based on eclipse) and a Rails-specific ide 
called RadRails, also based on Eclipse. jEdit, though a java editor, has 
superb bindings for Ruby and Rails too. There's Komodo (commercial) and 
FreeRide (just google for these names) and there are some excellent 
debuggers too.

HTH,
Vamsee.
From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Wed Mar 22 22:01:02 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Thu Mar 23 11:31:20 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Regarding udev and usb
In-Reply-To: <a54a308e0603221925h3877dacbu5e8844a6dafe28e2@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060323060102.1505.qmail@web50205.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi Chakkaradeep and others,

--- Chakkaradeep C C <chaks.yoper@gmail.com> wrote:
> Atlast after series of attempts and getting to know
> how udev manages and
> what HAL is 

Now that you have done your homework ...

> It is done with udev. What happens when you plug in
> an device?. The kernel
> identifies it as usb device, 

Its actually the host controller device driver
(EHCI/OHCI/UHCI) that identifies the device. There is
a Port Status/Control register for each host
controller, and the Connect Status Change bit is set
to 1 when a device is plugged in.

EHCI specification:
http://www.intel.com/technology/usb/ehcispec.htm

The basic idea of USB in Linux is like this:

  application
       |
    usbcore.ko 
       |
ehci-hcd/uhci-hcd/ohci-hcd

usbcore interacts with low level hardware, implements
hub operations, and also interacts with application
(client and class drivers).

> kernel action that is taking place is "add" this new
> device by loading the
> appropiate modules.

... only if the drivers are not loaded during boot
time.

> So here, the kernel sends the
> "add" message to the udev
> to get the device node created.The udev creates it.

> thumbdrives having only one
> partition(/dev/sda).It doesnt work for USB Mass
> Storage Devices where you
> have more than one partition(/dev/sda1,/dev/sda2
> etc.,).Need to dig around a
> bit deeper for this.

Which kernel are you talking about? In 2.6 kernels,
the USB device enumeration, block device drivers have
changed and it can detect multiple partitions as well.

 sda: p1 p2 p4

Try, OPTIONS="all_partitions".

well, it was very confusing to get to know what is the use of udev and hal
and hotplug and difference between them!

> It is done with udev. What happens when you plug in
> > an device?. The kernel
> > identifies it as usb device,
>
> Its actually the host controller device driver
> (EHCI/OHCI/UHCI) that identifies the device. There is
> a Port Status/Control register for each host
> controller, and the Connect Status Change bit is set
> to 1 when a device is plugged in.
>
> EHCI specification:
> http://www.intel.com/technology/usb/ehcispec.htm
>
> The basic idea of USB in Linux is like this:
>
>   application
>        |
>     usbcore.ko
>        |
> ehci-hcd/uhci-hcd/ohci-hcd
>
> usbcore interacts with low level hardware, implements
> hub operations, and also interacts with application
> (client and class drivers).


yes, thanks for the info :)

> kernel action that is taking place is "add" this new
> > device by loading the
> > appropiate modules.
>
> ... only if the drivers are not loaded during boot
> time.


obviously :)

> > "add" message to the udev

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Thu Mar 23 00:35:34 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Thu Mar 23 14:05:55 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Regarding udev and usb
In-Reply-To: <a54a308e0603222338j71cb8792u1484471e35b140b9@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060323083534.60238.qmail@web50207.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi Chakkaradeep and others,

--- Chakkaradeep C C <chaks.yoper@gmail.com> wrote:
> well, it was very confusing to get to know what is
> the use of udev and hal
> and hotplug and difference between them!

But, you persevered to learn. Hence, my reply and a
bit of help. [1]

> BUS=="usb", ACTION=="add", NAME="usb%n",
> RUN+="/usr/bin/mount-usb.sh usb%n"
> 
> the %n holds the kernel device number, that is ,
> suppose it creates at
> /dev/sda1, the kernel number is 1 and /dev/sda3, it
> is 3. So for /dev/sda it
> is nothing (i hope this is correct). 

Basically /dev/sda is the device filename for a
particular device.

/dev/sda1, /dev/sda2, /dev/sda3, et. al. represent the
partitions/blocks in /dev/sda.

> The above rule
> actually creates
> /dev/usb and so usb%n is probably ok now. Then, i
> pass the same as argument
> to the script.There comes the problem, when i check
> for the command line
> argument it is usb1 where it should have been usb. I
> have no idea how this
> got changed!. 

Probably, usb bus 1?

> Another notable point is if i do eject
> /dev/usb1, 

Always eject from the mount point, /mnt/whatever or
/media/whatever, that your distro uses.

As a user you only access the devices through the
mount point. Never touch the device files.

When you access your files through the mount point,
through syscalls the device files are accessed for
read/write operation. Something like:

 mount point    (user-space)
     | 
    VFS         (kernek-space)
     |
   SCSI
     |
  block device driver
     |
  ehci-hcd
     |
  hardware

Have fun.

[1] I don't like spoon-feeding.

SK

   Hello Luggies,

   Sub: Not able to login as root in FC4
   First let me tell how the problem started. I have been using GNOME as my
   default window manager from the day i started using my FC4. I had selected
   automatic login into my login id, the first time the system boots up ie at
   first login. It was fine for such a long time. Last week, i though of
   using KDE for sometime. When i logged out from GNOME and logged in into
   KDE, it dint ask me the usual question it 'used to' ask... whether i want
   to have KDE for this particuar session or want it to be made default ?
   But, i still thought nothing was wrong. Then , i googled for changing the
   default window manager.

   The first web site told me to alter/create a file ~/.xinitrc and include
   "exec startkde" which i tried but nothing changed. During that time, i was
   able to login as root after loging off from my login. Refer:
   http://www.tuxfiles.org/linuxhelp/changeman.html

   With prashant's help i found another website which told me another
   alternate method to change my default window manager. It asked to open
   "/etc/sysconfig/desktop" and change the "DESKTOP=GNOME" to "DESKTOP=KDE"
   and also add "DISPLAYMANAGER=KDE" in the nest line. I changed this in
   Emacs and rebooted the machine. Then, the default manager got changed to
   KDE and i have been using it for a weeks time.

   Yesterday, when I was using Synaptic Package Manager, it wasnt respoding
   so i treid to kill the proces.. First with Ksysgaurd but it said it cldnt
   kill syanptic as it was root's process. Then, i tried kill pid of syanptic
   using -su. This too failed to give results.

   When i logged in today, it still said syanptic was running. So, i decided
   to login as root and try whether i would be able ot kill it. When i logged
   out of KDE and tried loging in as root, the login reported that "root
   login not allowed". I changed the login screen to "Happy GNOME with
   browser" which shows what all the available logins at the login screen. To
   my surprise, it showed me no root as the available logins. Then, i removed
   the "DISPLAYMANAGER=KDE" line from /etc/sysconfig/desktop thinkig it might
   have some effect. Also noted tht, the login screen took time to change
   from blue curve to 'happy gnome' ( which occured only after i removed the
   line, which might have been coincidence also).

   Now, my total login and window manager is literaly in a mess. I am not
   able to Login as ROOT ! :((

   Kindly help me what to do ?! As I am leaving for Arunai LDD on sat, tomm
   evening will ve a testing time for me to correct there things :|

On 3/23/06, Parthan SR <parth.technofreak@gmail.com> wrote:
>
>    With prashant's help i found another website which told me another
>    alternate method to change my default window manager. It asked to open
>    "/etc/sysconfig/desktop" and change the "DESKTOP=GNOME" to "DESKTOP=KDE"
>    and also add "DISPLAYMANAGER=KDE" in the nest line. I changed this in
>    Emacs and rebooted the machine. Then, the default manager got changed to
>    KDE and i have been using it for a weeks time.

The recommended method is to create your own $HOME/.xsession file
(which should have execute permissions) and append your favorite
window manager there.

>
>    Now, my total login and window manager is literaly in a mess. I am not
>    able to Login as ROOT ! :((

Can you login as root from the console?  You can switch to console
mostly using Ctrl+Alt+F1.  Also, check your $HOME/.xsession-errors
file.

I think you would have grub installed. While booting your system thru grub,
press "e" and in the append "3" to the "kernel" line, you will go into
runlevel 3,without GUI.Check your stuff there.And form there type "xinit" to
check for X window, if everything goes well, you will get a xterm , type
exit and come out.Now type "startx", and check what happens.

Have Fun!

I hope this might help you to check your system functioning or not.

On 3/23/06, Parthan SR <parth.technofreak@gmail.com> wrote:
>   Hello Luggies,
>
>   Sub: Not able to login as root in FC4
>
>   The first web site told me to alter/create a file ~/.xinitrc and include
 "/etc/sysconfig/desktop" and change the "DESKTOP=GNOME" to "DESKTOP=KDE"
>   and also add "DISPLAYMANAGER=KDE" in the nest line. I changed this in

another way u could have done tht us by using the following cmd,

switchdesk KDE.

The above method changes the conf for only one user, whereas wht u
have done basically changes the system defaults.





>   out of KDE and tried loging in as root, the login reported that "root
>   login not allowed". I changed the login screen to "Happy GNOME with

>   the "DISPLAYMANAGER=KDE" line from /etc/sysconfig/desktop thinkig it might
>>   Now, my total login and window manager is literaly in a mess. I am not
>   able to Login as ROOT ! :((


There are two things u have to understand....


1. Login is controlled by the display manager prog.

KDE in REDHAT system by default stops ROOT login.  to change this....

/etc/X11/xdm/kdmrc

file.

2. Window managers have nothing to do with DISPLAY MANAGERS. which
means u can still load kde from gdm or GNOME from kdm.

gdm in Redhat system by defaults allow root logins....
to prevent this u can edit
/etc/X11/gdm/gdm.conf

or

menu->system settings -> loginscreen  ( gdm conf tool in graphics.)


regards,
kiran

Hi Kannan,

>> My point of about kref
>>
>> ----------------------
>>
>> Used when the multiple threads are involved within
>> the driver.
>>
>> I am not sure whether this can be when there are no
>> thread within the
>> driver and to control the Process synchronization.
>
>Code should always be such that it will work when
>multiple processes/threads are involved.

I understand that this kind of usage is just to maintain & track the
proper references to usage count of a structure and doest help in
locking.

>> In that case kref_put should be called in close
>> context or any error
>> context. Right?
>>
>> Yes, I find these two being issued in the
>> usb-skeleton driver.
>
>... and also extensively in 2.6 device drivers when
>they bring in kobjects, ksets, and ksubsystems.

Ok.

>> But, I find additional kref_put() call in
>> disconnect? That too without
>> any condition checking? Why do I need it here?
>
>In 2.4 kernels, to allocate resources to processes,
>and to know how many are using it you will use the
>following functions: atomic_inc(), atomic_dec() et.
>al.
>
>Similarily in 2.6 kernels, with the integration of the
>new device class model, you will be using kref_get(),
>kref_put() et. al.
>
>Source: http://lxr.linux.no/source/lib/kref.c#L30
>
>I'd definitely recommend that you read "Chapter 14:
>The Linux Device Model" from Linux Device Drivers by
>Alessandro Rubini and Jonathan Corbett.

I will read it.

From binand at gmail.com  Fri Mar 24 13:17:36 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Fri Mar 24 17:47:43 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Sendmail Update
Message-ID: <d2a92d610603240417v2eb347day@mail.gmail.com>

I didn't see anyone else posting this, so here goes...

After several years of exemplary security record, now it appears that
a remotely exploitable vulnerability has been discovered in recent
versions of Sendmail. Some details are here:

http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/834865

Sendmail Inc.'s own advisory is here:

http://www.sendmail.com/company/advisory/

I have seen advisories of Redhat, Debian, Mandriva, Gentoo and others
(eg: FreeBSD has an advisory at
ftp://ftp.freebsd.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/advisories/FreeBSD-SA-06:13.sendmail.asc).
You should upgrade Sendmail asap, even if your installation is not
Internet exposed.

Binand

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Fri Mar 24 04:56:32 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Fri Mar 24 18:26:59 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Login Problem _ Root unable to log in

Hi again,

--- Binand Sethumadhavan <binand@gmail.com> wrote:
> Yep, again. Users and Superusers are different. But
> my question was
> why discourage root logins specifically from X
> Windows as opposed to
> console login or ssh root@somehost?

As root, you have full control of the system. Newbies
*can* open a terminal/nautilus and see all files under
/ that are accessible. Knowingly or unknowingly if
they try to change files or modify them or delete
them, it will be difficult to recover them by
themselves, and they wouldn't even know how to explain
what they did.

Sometimes, even experienced folks might mis-spell a rm
*~ for rm *, and can cause all the files to be
deleted. There are always permission checks for users
before they open files, execute code etc., which is
not the case for root user.

One of my colleagues logged into X as root (Red Hat)
and mistakenly deleted the /lib/libc.so.6 file. Don't
ask me why. The system wouldn't boot thereafter -
obviously. I had to boot from Knoppix LiveCD, remotely
copy the file from another identical system, and
restore it.

Regards,

SK

From mukundjb at esntechnologies.co.in  Fri Mar 24 18:24:44 2006
From: mukundjb at esntechnologies.co.in (Mukund JB.)

Subject: [Ilugc] Q&A About Linux Core
Message-ID: <3AEC1E10243A314391FE9C01CD65429B37FFE9@mail.esn.co.in>


Dear Linux Lovers,

This is regarding sharing my knowledge updates on Linux Scheduling and
concurrency issues. This will help new people as a reference
understanding the real core Linux OS.

Please correct me in case if I am wrong anywhere & help me produce
proper note on "kernel Scheduling & locks".

About the interrupt preemptions
-------------------------------
Common notion:
ISR is not preemptable

NO, ISR is preemptable. The ISR routine is preemptable only due to the
occurrence of another interrupt in the parse of handling the current
Interrupt. 

My questions on this
--------------------
If so, will this not propagate and cause the delay in handling the ISR1.

Example: if ISR1 is preempted by ISR2. ISR2 is preempted by ISR3. I
guess ISR2 will be executed completely and then give the chance to the
ISR1. Am I right?
In that case, the Execution is ISR1 is delayed. Is that not a problem?

About Locking:
------------------

The reasons for having locks in the kernel are to provide kernel
features like kernel preemption, multiple contexts in kernel,
self-relinquishing multi tasking & multiprocessing environment.

-- Why due to Kernel Preemption 
When a kernel module is being executed in a critical region and if the
scheduler preempts the running process

-- Why due to multiple contexts 
When a kernel module is being executed in a critical region in a read
context and if the scheduler preempts the running process and executes
the some other process using the same kernel module to write (write
context).

-- Why due to self-relinquishing or sleeping
Self-relinquishing means sleeping or giving the processor by own (Kernel
module). 

-- Why due to multi tasking
Multi tasking is achieved through preemption & when the process in some
context sleeps for a while

-- Why due to multi processing
Multi processing means same code can execute on different processors at
the same time. In that case p1 & p2 processes can try to use shared data
at the same time. This causes corruption of data.

Questions to Experts
--------------------
	On 2.6, why does a sleep in the ISR cause hanging of system.

Hardware Questions:
-------------------

Regarding Programmable interrupt controller, will it generate interrupts
continuously irrespective of INT ACK.

I mean, if an interrupt occurred and that is being serviced, is there a
chance of another interrupt being received from PIC?


Regards,
Mukund Jampala

Gopalarathnam Venkatesan wrote:

>Do you do that? logging to some host using "ssh root@somehost"?  Thats
>bad anyway.
>
>Why can't you use sudo(1) whenever necessary?  I'm just curious.
>
>  
>
+1. I'm no linux sysadmin, but from what I know, the reason you should 
not do ssh root@something.com is because it can be brute-forced. Of 
course, good sysadmins always have non-trivial passwords, but a good 
best practice is to disable root login. Add yourself to /etc/sudoers. 
Then, you can give selective rights to your inexperienced sysadmins.

A sysadmin responsible for mail server can only touch postfix related 
commands, and such. You can sleep better knowing that you have the only 
full-powered sudo login. If you can also create a non-trivial login like 
b0099dx@something.com, brute-force chances are that much lesser. I sigh 
at my server's /etc/var/syslog where in I see brute force attempts  for 
accounts like root@blabla.com, sue@blabla.com, pete@blabla.com, etc. 
Very crude way of breaking in, but it happens.


HTH,
Vamsee.

	<4cba61b90603240544s4ecc0f19hbb99b6b03b17c7e3@mail.gmail.com>

On 24/03/06, Gopalarathnam Venkatesan <gopal@gopalarathnam.com> wrote:
> Do you do that? logging to some host using "ssh root@somehost"?  Thats
> bad anyway.

True. Real admins will have "PermitRootLogin without-password" in
their sshd_config anyway.

> Why can't you use sudo(1) whenever necessary?  I'm just curious.

No reason. But sudo is a delegation utility. It cannot be a full
substitute for root user. For example:

1. Most people get tired of doing sudo this, sudo that and finally
will discover sudo bash. Beats the whole purpose.
2. Sudo doesn't set the environment properly (bug or feature,
depending on how you look at it). Run sudo env to see what I mean.
3. If you provide someone sudo access to a program that allows shell
escape (or even simple shell commands), it is easy to break out of the
sudo jail.
4. Sudo is useless in system recovery.
5. Several management software (some of the RAID cards I use, for
example) require root passwords anyway.
6. Lastly, Getting shell redirections to work inside sudo is a real
PITA. Eg: sudo grep someuser /etc/shadow > /etc/someotherfile - try
it. Won't work.

Binand
From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Fri Mar 24 08:45:07 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Fri Mar 24 22:15:15 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Login Problem _ Root unable to log in
In-Reply-To: <d2a92d610603240532o6818255at@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060324164507.93501.qmail@web50209.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi Binand,

--- Binand Sethumadhavan <binand@gmail.com> wrote:
> Root access, be it via su root or X login as root
> are all equally
> dangerous. The whole question is WHY one of those is
> specifically
> discouraged over the others.

When you use a console as root, your only major input
mode is your keyboard. So, you will need to type in
commands, command options, arguments to execute. So,
before you hit enter, you will always look at the
commands and make sure its what you really want to do.

On the other hand, when working with X, most people
that I have seen use the mouse/touchpad/trackpoint. It
takes far less "clicks" to move around with the
filesystem, application and make changes easily. So,
when using X as root, its much easier to screw up your
system than when using the console.

My assumption is that most of the time X users don't
use the keyboard, except for text input.

Just my thoughts,

SK

On 3/24/06, Aniruddha Udipi <aniruddha.udipi@gmail.com> wrote:
> I am a novice with Linux and have just installed Ubuntu 5.04. My
> screen resolution is very poor (640X480).

Choose the right horizontal and vertical frequency as specified in
your Monitor manual.
Don't just choose a random value - it might damage your monitor.

For example, i have the following configuration
Section "Monitor"
        Identifier      "SyncMaster 793s"
        Option          "DPMS"
        HorizSync       30-70
        VertRefresh     50-160
EndSection

--
Vijairaj

From gopal at gopalarathnam.com  Sun Mar 26 12:10:07 2006
From: gopal at gopalarathnam.com (Gopalarathnam Venkatesan)
Date: Sun Mar 26 12:10:18 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Changing the order of process in initscripts
In-Reply-To: <48bd74c50603251411h468a736ax9e233e82cee08a76@mail.gmail.com>
References: <48bd74c50603251411h468a736ax9e233e82cee08a76@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <4cba61b90603252240k10ee0cd5y4ba7bb09eb04f633@mail.gmail.com>

On 3/26/06, peevee <peevee.chaitanya@gmail.com> wrote:
> Hi,
> I want to change the boot order of a process in initscript,
> My reqiurement is that , I have to make my entrance demon to start before
> hal demon.... in runlevel 5...
> so can anyone tell me how to do it? I am usin SUSE 10,
> I think I have to change the  xx number in SxxProcess SxxProcess of
> /etc/init.d/rc5.d/ or /etc/rc.d/rc5.d/ (i am not sure where to change)
>
> so can you guys tell how to change it so that the changes are consistant...

Almost all of the distros/OSes (I've seen this in Solaris too) include
a README in the /etc/init.d directory which explains the order of
execution of the scripts in detail.

Anyway, the real start/stop script lives in /etc/init.d and is
symlinked to the corresponding run-level something like:

/etc/init.d/rc5.d/S19haldaemon -> ../haldaemon
/etc/init.d/rc5.d/K02haldaemon -> ../haldaemon

where S indicates start, K indicates stop/kill.  The numbers between
the S/K and the link name determines the order of start/stop.

If you want entraced to start before haldaemon (I don't know why you
need to do this), make the number before 20, something like
S10entranced.

HTH.

PS. Read the README.

--
Gopalarathnam Venkatesan
http://gopalarathnam.com/

From lug at chandrashekar.info  Sun Mar 26 23:15:14 2006
From: lug at chandrashekar.info (=?iso-8859-1?Q?Chandrashekar=20Babu.?=)
Date: Sun Mar 26 23:15:31 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Changing the order of process in initscripts
Message-ID: <20060326174514.10359.qmail@server301.com>

Hi!

>  I want to change the boot order of a process in initscript,
>  My reqiurement is that , I have to make my entrance demon to start before
>  hal demon.... in runlevel 5...

On RedHat and most RedHat based distributions which use
the 'chkconfig' program to enable/disable startup services for
the default runlevel,  you can simply edit the service script
(found in /etc/init.d/ directory) and modify the commented
line that reads something like below:
       # chkconfig: 345 98 02
The first number in the above example (345) determines
the runlevels that this service would be enabled by default
(runlevel 3, 4 and 5 in this case). The second number indicates
the startup order (S98) and the third number is the kill
order (K02).

>  so can anyone tell me how to do it? I am usin SUSE 10,
>  I think I have to change the??xx number in SxxProcess SxxProcess of
>  /etc/init.d/rc5.d/ or /etc/rc.d/rc5.d/ (i am not sure where to change)

The runlevel directories (rc[0-6].d) would be located in either /etc/init.d/
or /etc/rc.d/ or in /etc/ directory itself - it all depends on the distribution.
In most cases, it would be located in one of the directories like
/etc/rc.d/ and  symlinked to other locations.

I suspect that SuSE linux follows similar structure (like RedHat) for 
determining the default startup/shutdown order. Open the service 
startup file - /etc/init.d/entrace or /etc/init.d/haldaemon and check 
for the first few commented lines to find if it has a '# chkconfig' line 
in it. If you find it, just change the second number of that line
in /etc/init.d/entrance to a lower value than what you would find in
/etc/init.d/haldaemon to make it start before haldaemon.

After modifying the number(s), run the following commands:
   chkconfig haldaemon reset
   chkconfig entrance reset
The above method works on RedHat/Fedora Core, I hope it 
does on SuSE too.

OTOH, you could manually rename/recreate the symlinks for
/etc/init.d/haldaemon and /etc/init.d/entrace in
/etc/rc5.d/ directory as shown by the following example:
   ln -s /etc/init.d/haldaemon /etc/rc5.d/S98haldaemon
   ln -s /etc/init.d/entrance /etc/rc5.d/S97entrance
[Doing so on RedHat might cause problems if you use
'chkconfig' program later on].

Cheers,

--
Chandrashekar Babu.
http://www.chandrashekar.info/

Hi,

>  gcc is coming along with all distribution or we have to install it seperately

Depends on your distribution and your installation method. Most distributions
would not install gcc if you perform a minimal install or skip selection of 
"Development tools/software" in a customized installation.  A couple of desktop 
Linux distributions that come on a single CD (Live distros, mostly) may not have 
gcc bundled with them.

Date: Sun Mar 26 23:45:15 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Kernel 2.6.16 compile error!
Message-ID: <20060326181507.15132.qmail@server301.com>

Hi,

>  I compiled the 2.6.16 kernel. It is giving me the following error during
>  compilation..
>  
>  drivers/built-in.o: In function `cciss_update_non_disk_devices':
>  cciss.c:(.text+0x7d947): undefined reference to `scsi_device_types'
>  cciss.c:(.text+0x7dad0): undefined reference to `scsi_device_types'
>  cciss.c:(.text+0x7daf8): undefined reference to `scsi_device_types'
>  cciss.c:(.text+0x7dc7f): undefined reference to `scsi_device_types'
>  drivers/built-in.o: In function `cciss_proc_write':
>  cciss.c:(.text+0x7de94): undefined reference to `scsi_host_alloc'
>  cciss.c:(.text+0x7df01): undefined reference to `scsi_add_host'
>  cciss.c:(.text+0x7df0d): undefined reference to `scsi_scan_host'
>  cciss.c:(.text+0x7df15): undefined reference to `scsi_host_put'
>  drivers/built-in.o: In function `cciss_remove_one':
>  cciss.c:(.text+0x7f3d6): undefined reference to `scsi_remove_host'
>  cciss.c:(.text+0x7f3dd): undefined reference to `scsi_host_put'

Seems like you have enabled "Compaq Smart Array 5xxx controllers" 
support (CONFIG_BLK_CPQ_CISS_DA) without enabling scsi device
support (CONFIG_SCSI). Enable scsi device support and try rebuilding
again.

>  drivers/built-in.o: In function `ns_init_module':
>  nandsim.c:(.init.text+0xb9c2): undefined reference to `nand_scan'
>  nandsim.c:(.init.text+0xbb52): undefined reference to `nand_flash_ids'
>  nandsim.c:(.init.text+0xbce5): undefined reference to `nand_default_bbt'
>  drivers/built-in.o: In function `ns_cleanup_module':
>  nandsim.c:(.exit.text+0xcc3): undefined reference to `nand_release'

Try enabling "NAND Device Support" in Memory Technology Devices
Section (CONFIG_MTD_NAND) and try rebuilding again.

--
Chandrashekar Babu.
http://www.chandrashekar.info/
From vaslin at gmail.com  Mon Mar 27 09:31:27 2006
From: vaslin at gmail.com (Vasudevan A)
Date: Mon Mar 27 09:31:35 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Installing Nvidia driver in FC5
Message-ID: <f6a0291a0603262001k1bdef95cx678dfe0cffe658e8@mail.gmail.com>

Hi,
here is a guide for installing nvidia display driver in FC5

su -
cd /etc/yum.repos.d/
wget http://people.redhat.com/davej/kernels/Fedora/FC5/kernels.repo
yum install rpm-build
yum install kernel-devel -y
yum update kernel kernel-devel -y
mkdir /root/nvidia
cd /root/nvidia
wget http://www.leemhuis.info/files/fedorarpms/MISC.lvn/graphics/xorg-x11-drv-nvidia-1.0.8178-0.lvn.5.i386.rpm
wget http://www.leemhuis.info/files/fedorarpms/MISC.lvn/graphics/nvidia-kmod-1.0.8178-0.lvn.3.2.6.15_1.1881_FC5.src.rpm
reboot
select the new kernel, then:
su -
cd /root/nvidia
rpmbuild --rebuild --target `uname -m` nvidia-kmod-*.src.rpm
cp -a /usr/src/redhat/RPMS/`uname -m`/kmod-nvidia* ./
rpm -Uvh kmod-*nvidia*-1.0.8178-0.*.rpm
xorg-x11-drv-nvidia-1.0.8178-0.lvn.5.i386.rpm
modprobe nvidia
chkconfig nvidia-glx on
service nvidia-glx start
nvidia-xconfig
reboot


Bye
Vasudevan

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Sun Mar 26 22:25:59 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Mon Mar 27 11:56:17 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [Photos] FOSSE 2006, Arunai Engineering College,
	Thiruvannamalai
Message-ID: <20060327062559.77346.qmail@web50210.mail.yahoo.com>

Greetings!

The photos (more than 120) taken during the two-day
FOSS Exhibit held on March 25-26, 2006 organized by
ILUGC, and NRC-FOSS at Arunai Engineering College,
Thiruvannamalai, Tamil Nadu are available at:

http://www.shakthimaan.com/Mambo/gallery/album26

I would like to thank the management, faculty of
Arunai Engineering College for their wonderful
support. My hearty congratulations to the students for
their valiant efforts in this event. 

Special thanks to our fellow ILUGC and NRC-FOSS folks,
and Dr. Srinivasan for taking the initiative. We had a
very good time :)

A brief summary of the events and the fun we had :

Day I : Saturday, March 25, 2006
--------------------------------

* Team I began on Saturday, March 25, 2006 morning by
0500 IST. I was picked up first, then Suman
(Triplicane), Dr. Srinivasan (Saidapet), Aanjhan and
Parthan (Kathibara junction), Raman and Bhaskar
(Tambaram). Aanjhan came by bus from Bangalore to
Chennai, the previous night and joined Parthan in the
morning. 

* We did break for breakfast. We got back in the
Toyota Qualis after breakfast and were about to leave
when we realized that Suman was not there. We found
him in the hotel.

* We arrived at around 0830 IST in the morning. As
usual, college formalities and inauguration. 

* Raman began the day's proceedings with introduction
to FLOSS, followed by Fedora Core installation. Team
2a arrived and were introduced. They moved to the labs
to train the students. After installation demo, I
discussed about career opportunities with FLOSS.
Meanwhile Team 2b, Asokan and Thyagurajan, had arrived
and introduced themselves. Suman gave an introduction
on Qt programming. 

* We had lunch between 1300-1400.

* Post-lunch session began with an excellent
presentation by Asokan Pichai on shell scripting and
the power of scripting. Thyagurajan gave a talk on
GLAMP after Asokan's talk.

* Tea break was at 1530 IST.

* Two folks from Sun Microsystems, Bangalore had come,
Arindam and Moinak. So we had to give them some time
for a session. They gave a demo of Opensolaris and
wanted more developers for the same.

* Aanjhan spoke on how students can contribute to
FLOSS.

* At 1700 we moved to the labs to help the other teams
who were training students. We finally left at 1900 to
the hotel. When we reached the hotel, one of the
students told us that we had left someone behind.
Guess who? Suman. Nevertheless, he was dropped to the
hotel.

* We had good dinner, and in Room #203, Saravanan,
Raman, Parthan and myself had good discussions about
FLOSS and ILUGC activities. We hit the sack only at
midnight.

Day II, Sunday, March 26, 2006
------------------------------

* Many folks visited the temple in the morning, and
then went to the college to help in the stalls.
Preparations were in full-swing with students helping
in setting up the stalls, putting up banners, etc.

* Team III arrived in the morning.

* The auditorium session began around 1000. Audience
were school students, college students, and general
public. I introduced them to FLOSS, showed the *nix
desktop environment, software that they can use with
GNU/Linux etc.

* The chief guest, M. R. Rajagopalan, Director, C-DAC,
Chennai inaugurated the stalls. They along with the
college management and administration folks then came
to the auditorium for a quick inauguration session.

* Lunch was at 1330.

* The stalls were bustling with activity. 

* We resumed sessions in the auditorium at 1500 and
Moinak introduced folks on Bellenix and OpenSolaris.
Arindam then began talking about core kernel hacking
to newbies (hmmm...) and continued on and on and on
till 1700, and most of them left for the stalls [1]. I
was happy they moved to the stalls as they were to
close by 1700. We didn't have time to play
The.Code.linux or have a Q&A discussion session
(interactive, like in day one). [2] 

* There was a big thanks-giving at the end of the day
to all volunteers, and we departed at 1800. 

Overall, I was overwhelmed by the enthusiasm of the
AEC students, and given a chance, I would go there
again.

My apologies, if I have missed any names. Please feel
free to add to the above and share your experience.

Thanking you all once again,

SK

--

[1] Know the audience to whom you are addressing, and
stick to the time limit. A request to colleges: When
we plan workshops, we plan it well in advance. If you
get new folks coming in on the day of the workshop and
wanting to do sessions, it becomes really tight to
squeeze everybody in. It becomes even difficult when
they don't stick to the time limit. 

[2] I will take this in the good spirit of "group
dynamics" (?) and as a valuable experience.

From: Bram Moolenaar <Bram@...>
Date: Fri Mar 24, 2006  11:29 pm
Subject: Vim sponsorship changes

The past few years many people have sponsored my work on Vim.  Now
version 7 is nearing completion, beta testing will start soon, very
soon.  A big thanks to all who supported me!  I would not have been able
to do this without your help.

But things are going to change.  I have accepted a job offer and will go
back to a full time job in a few months.  To avoid speculation and
rumours: I am going to work for Google in Zurich.  Fortunately I can
spend part of my time on Vim.  But it will obviously be less than the
past few years when I was working 150% of my time on Vim.

I will no longer need sponsorship to survive.  Therefore, starting the
end of March, all money given for Vim sponsorship and registration will
go to the project in Kibaale, Uganda.  And no, this is not an April
fools joke.

The voting will continue as before.  And seeing people give money will
motivate me to keep working on Vim.  The children need the help much
more than me anyway.  Thus please keep sending money!

--

Hi guys: I am very happy about the grand show at Arunai and the very
positive  sentiments from all ILUG-C members. As you are aware, NRCFOSS has
the college interaction as a major activity and you (we -- well I am a LUG
member too!) are making it easy. There have been enquiries from a number of
colleges. Am sure Jaya Engg would like to up their ante. We also need more
shows to spread the word about the new electives, projects, etc.

Arunai guys themselves are keen to follow up. I have made them an offer --
to provide project ideas, initial reading materials and mentors. They should
do some decent projects, let us say by July, and make another big show : now
with their own "products". [The Dept of IT -- read Mr. Ravichandran -- has
already staked a claim to organize the event!].

I have also asked them to work out an event for the school audience. The
management runs the Jeeva-Velu International School and the schools in and
around Thiruvannamalai are the potential resources providing students for
the college. The AEC lecturers and students, assisted by LUG members can
manage the show.

By the way, Mr. Atul Chitnis had expressed a keen desire to be present at
the next FOSS show at Arunai.

As NRCFOSS member, it is also our responsiblity to help all other colleges.
Have asked the C-DAC FOSS team to join the activities. We could have a small
group working on the plan and modalities for the next 3-4 months activities.


Of course, you guys could come up with alternate suggestions.

Thanks once again, Srinivasan.

From mukundjb at esntechnologies.co.in  Wed Mar 29 00:02:00 2006
From: mukundjb at esntechnologies.co.in (Mukund JB.)
Date: Wed Mar 29 00:02:47 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Synchronization Clarifications
Message-ID: <3AEC1E10243A314391FE9C01CD65429B3B43E3@mail.esn.co.in>


Dear Linux Team,

I am working more on synchronization in kernels. 
I just have a set of basic conceptions in mind and I need clarity on few
issues. Please can someone follow up with comments on these lines below?

1) Sleep or schedule related calls should not be used in between
Spinlocks.

2) Is the interruptible_sleep_on_timeout() call based on timer interrupt
(or internal tick counter loop)?

3) Spinlocks have no effect on UNI-Processor machines. 

4) I guess interrupts will be served even when the spinlocks are held
except for spinlock_irqsave(). Am I right?

5) On a kernel compiled with preemption enabled (Multiprocessor), will
the CRT+ C work to break the spinlock which helps when I use semaphores
with interruptible support.

6) On a preemptive kernel, Spinlock() does not disable the interrupts
rather it disables preemption. I guess it mean, that if an interrupt
occurs, the ISR is executed and returns back to the same process
executing before it. If 
We will not have this to be addressed in 2.4.x kernels as the preemption
is by default disabled in kernel.

7) This is the case with all times of spinlocks i.e. spin_lock_irq,
spin_lock_irqsave, spin_lock.


Regards,
Mukund Jampala

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Tue Mar 28 19:27:04 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Wed Mar 29 08:57:30 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [Photos] FOSSE 2006, Arunai Engineering College,
	Thiruvannamalai
In-Reply-To: <f190c8a50603281015m6dbd015aie580e38b957b9a47@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060329032704.35814.qmail@web50209.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

--- Aparajit Raghavan <aparajit@gmail.com> wrote:
> This looks more like USB Mass storage rather than
> PTP..

They are different.

USB mass storage is a USB class specification driver
for mass storage drivers which is positioned on top of
the USB driver.

PTP is also a USB class specification - USB Still
Imaging class specification.

  USB mass storage    PTP
         \            /
    USB core implementation          
                |
           EHCI HCD

Free Software with PTP support:
http://ptp.sourceforge.net/

libptp:
http://libptp.sourceforge.net/README

SK

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Tue Mar 28 21:01:50 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Wed Mar 29 10:32:19 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Synchronization Clarifications
In-Reply-To: <3AEC1E10243A314391FE9C01CD65429B3B43E3@mail.esn.co.in>
Message-ID: <20060329050150.55519.qmail@web50213.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi Mukund,

I'll try and answer to the best of my knowledge. I'd
definitely recommend "Understanding the Linux Kernel",
3rd edition. Its now available in India.

--- "Mukund JB." <mukundjb@esntechnologies.co.in>
wrote:

> 1) Sleep or schedule related calls should not be
> used in between
> Spinlocks.

... else they might lead to a deadlock.
 
> 2) Is the interruptible_sleep_on_timeout() call
> based on timer interrupt
> (or internal tick counter loop)?

By internal tick counter loop, are you referring to
jiffies? Then, yes, I guess.

http://lxr.linux.no/source/include/linux/timer.h
 
> 3) Spinlocks have no effect on UNI-Processor
> machines. 

"The kernel is a highly multithreaded environment.
Unless some data structure is private to a single
thread of context you have to do appropiate locking
for it.

No kernel code should be written on the assumption
that you will never be SMP, because kernel hackers who
got free, big, 64-way SMP machines will hate you
forever. And some locking is required on uniprocessor
machines as well. "

http://www.linuxgrill.com/anonymous/fire/netfilter/kernel-hacking-HOWTO-5.html

http://www.cs.uiowa.edu/~jones/opsys/spring02/notes/24.html
 
> 5) On a kernel compiled with preemption enabled
> (Multiprocessor), will
> the CRT+ C work to break the spinlock which helps
> when I use semaphores
> with interruptible support.

CRT + C? You mean Control + C? When running in
supervisor mode, the user doesn't get control/access
to kernel code or its operations.
 
> If 
> We will not have this to be addressed in 2.4.x
> kernels as the preemption
> is by default disabled in kernel.

http://linuxdevices.com/articles/AT3479098230.html
 
You might also want to try the kernelnewbies mailing
list:

http://mail.nl.linux.org/kernelnewbies/

Have fun,

SK

This issue has been fixed. The 'su' program in /bin
folder should have 'suid' bit in it. But it doesn't
have. Thatswhy non-root users were not able to switch
to another user.

Now I set 'suid' for 'su' program and its working now.


Sarav

>
>No kernel code should be written on the assumption

Check this, issue 
	down_interruptible();
	down_interruptible();

This will hand the terminal. After hanging you can come out of this by
pressing CTRL +C? It was woken up. I checked it. REASON is on interrupt
of keyboard, the all processes on semaphore is waken up and exited
finding that nothing is there to execute.

I just want to know, when using the spinlock, can we exit like this. I
guess NO, just because, interrupt will be handled and the same previous
process (as preemption is disabled when spinlocks are used) will resume
(spinover process).

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Wed Mar 29 05:08:00 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Wed Mar 29 18:38:08 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] USB OTG Clarifications
In-Reply-To: <3AEC1E10243A314391FE9C01CD65429B3B4544@mail.esn.co.in>
Message-ID: <20060329130800.73523.qmail@web50205.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

This is a very generic question. 

I'll answer it as relevant to Linux.

--- "Mukund JB." <mukundjb@esntechnologies.co.in>
wrote:
> I have read through the USB & OTG Specifications.
> I have understood the USB OTG leaves very less to
> the part of Software.

It depends on the implementation.

> Most of it is handled in the hardware i.e. in the el
> electrical and
> mechanical characteristics.

Nope. You need Linux driver support as well.
 
> But, I found that there was no clear statement
> mentioning whether the
> normal 2.0 Device which is unaware of OTG can work
> with it.

No, it will not work. The normal host which you see is
a standard A female end. For OTG, you need to use
mini-A and mini-B ends. Re-read the mechanical
characteristics.

> I understand normal USB 2.0 & USB 1.1 Devices do not
> support HNP & SRP?

Yes. 

> So, Can this kind Devices support OTG Hosts?

You mean talk with an OTG host. Yes, but they cannot
do HNP or SRP. For OTG support, hardware needs to have
support built-in.

> If I have a working USB Device & host firmware for a
> device, I will need
> to add few things at the protocol level, request
> level & Dual role
> handling.

Yes.

There is already OTG support included in 2.6 kernels.
For USB device operations, check the gadget drivers. 

Linux USB Gadget API:
http://www.linux-usb.org/gadget/

Chapter 6: USB OTG:
http://tali.admingilde.org/linux-docbook/gadget/ch06.html

Linux USB OTG on TI OMAP:
http://www.linux-usb.org/gadget/h2-otg.html

SK
