From tech at leatherlink.net  Wed Mar 29 22:16:36 2006
From: tech at leatherlink.net (LeatherLink)
Date: Wed Mar 29 22:25:02 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Arunai Engineering College - FOSSE06 - My experience
Message-ID: <32986.59.92.52.91.1143650796.squirrel@www.leatherlink.net>

I went to Arunai Engineering College only on Sunday morning.  From what
Raman had written earlier, I was somewhat prepared for the scale of the
event.

A prominent hoarding of Tux in the main market street  came as a pleasant
surprise. After years of seeing Linux only in niche mailing lists and
websites, it was a welcome change.

I spent the day at the database stall manned by 2 final year students and
4 junior students of Computer Science department.They had prepared two
pages of talking points,  a one page handout to visitors and two systems
with MySQL and PostgreSQL installed. They handled everything confidently
with their week long training.

 * They insisted that they are more comfortable with command line. * They
were highlighting the tab completion support in their presentation. *
They picked up minor points highlighted by any of the ilugc volunteers
and incorporated into their talk to the visitors.
 * The senior girls were bossing around the juniors a bit, pushing all the
talking to them :-).


In the morning, dozens of schools boys and girls were trooped around. Most
of them are in Higher Secondary classes. In my opinion, other than
registering the names of OS applications, they would not have carried back
much from the expo.

But, there were atleast half a dozen serious geeky/technical/academic
college students, who came to explore and went back with more conviction
about open source databases.  Some interesting discussions were around:

1. You people talk about source being open. Isn't it dangerous that anyone
can look at the code and exploit the weakness? How can our data be secure?
2. Windows is so easy and I am already familiar with it. What do I get
moving to open source?
3. Can I use open sourced code for my software and sell it as closed
source? 4. What does PostgreSQL do which Oracle can not do?

There was one guy from MIT who plans to do a project with PostgreSQL and
one ME student from Arunai Engineering who was interested in PostgreSQL
internals.

Overall, the commitment of the college's top management, efforts of ilugc
volunteers and the enthusiasm of the students made this a special event.
If this is an indication of things to come, open source development is in
for interesting times in India.

somethng like that_dll_is_missing in Windows.

Use APT that will resolve it for you. As Shakti says, Synaptic is the 
GUI front end.

What you need to do is learn APT.

Aniruddha Udipi wrote:
> Hi!
> I am a new user to linux and have installed Ubuntu 5.04, Hoary Hedgehog. I
> am unable to install any program...teh following errors are popping up. Is
> there any way I can set this right all at once or each problem individually?
>
>
> configure: error: zinf needs zlib installed
>
> *** The glib-config script installed by GLIB could not be found
> *** If GLIB was installed in PREFIX, make sure PREFIX/bin is in
> *** your path, or set the GLIB_CONFIG environment variable to the
> *** full path to glib-config.
> configure: error: *** GLIB >= 1.2.2 not installed - please install first ***
>
>   
Find if you have glib installed. you can find it by using the default 
package manger with ubuntu which i guess is apt-get. Do read the man 
page of apt-get.  If yes.. find what version of glib you have. 
"glib-config --version"  will tell you what version you have.  "which 
glib-config" will tell you where it is installed. Make sure that 
glib-config is in your path.
> *** Warning: No suitable gperf found. ***
>     The gperf package is essential for building ivl from
>     CVS sources, or modifying the parse engine of ivl itself.
>     You can get away without it when simply building from
>     snapshots or major releases.
>   
"$apt-get install gpref" .. should install  gpref.
> checking for flex... no
> *** Error: No suitable flex found. ***
>     Please install the 'flex' package.
>
>   
"$apt-get install flex"

I guess this was usefull.

From toufeeqh at gmail.com  Wed Mar 29 12:02:24 2006
From: toufeeqh at gmail.com (Toufeeq Hussain)

Subject: [Ilugc] Fwd: FW: [LIP] Call for Developers for the CSLinux project
In-Reply-To: <DEFD7B974A06EF4DA24EE07239EA7590AC9333@BLRKECMSG03.ad.infosys.com>
References: <DEFD7B974A06EF4DA24EE07239EA7590AC9333@BLRKECMSG03.ad.infosys.com>
Message-ID: <c293dd340603282232l19d69e44k53899d4b405c72bb@mail.gmail.com>

FYI,

Engineering students thinking of starting off a Distro-project can
help out with CSLinux.

-Toufeeq
[linux-india-programmers-admin@lists.sourceforge.net :: ] on  chose to say:

> Dear Linux hackers,
>
> As you may be aware, we, the Computer Science Linux
> User's Group, are attempting to make our own re-branded
> distribution of Linux based on Fedora Core 5.
>
> This distribution is aimed at having a customised set of
> packages that we need in our BCS/MCS/BE/ME/MCA/Diploma
> syllabus so that one set of three or four CDs can be moved
> around without carring peripheral CDs for Java, plugins,
> multimedia, etc.
>
> Moreover, we were mailed regularly by people that they
> had trouble setting up Postgres, PHP, tomcat, Perl, JDBC,
> etc. during their time of critical needs.
> It is definately not fair to expect people to learn how to
> configure these things at the last moment when practicals are
> declared within a week.
>
> Even if someone is capable of configuring these, it is
> likely that they may forget at the last moment and also
> likely that people wont want to spend time configuring stuff
> on the day previous to the exam at the cost of studying.
>
> For this purpose, we also aim to provide pre-configured
> RPMs and configuration scripts that can achieve this task
> within a few minutes. In fact, CSLinux version 1 released
> last year allowed even first year students to set up many
> things that TYs were having trouble with.
>
> This version will be aimed at pushing this simplicity
> and ease-of-use to the next level. With GUIs, web-based tools
> for remote management of nodes in labs, configuration
> replication scripts for applying common settings to multiple
> laboratory nodes, user management scripts for handling the
> thousads of users on college servers, etc.
>
> For more information on what's been going on in regard
> to CSLinux, you are encouraged to join the CSLUG group
> http://groups.yahoo.com/group/cslug
> and go through the archives
> http://groups.yahoo.com/group/cslug/message
> . We have also started a Wiki
> seedwiki.com/wiki/computer_science_linux_users_group/
> for simplifying this effort and the
> link to it can be found in he CSLUG archives.
>
> We request your participation, support and encouragement
> in this effort. Please do spread the word around.
>
> We need all sorts of people to help us out. We need
> graphics designers to design the themes, logos, images,
> wallpapers, bootscreens, etc. for CSLinux. We require people
> to modify the installer Anaconda. We need people to modify
> RPM files and change the default configuration in them. We
> need people to make and build binary RPMs out of source
> tarballs for packages whose RPMs that may not already be
> available or when
> i686 RPMs may not be available.
>
> We also need developers to develop the configuration
> scripts, the small tools that we will provide with CSLinux
> and changing initscripts.
>
> Finally and most importantly, we also require the
> BCS/MCS/BE/ME/MCA/Diploma community to contribute their
> academic projects to be put up on CSLinux. This is to
> encourage students to make professional-grade real-life
> applicable projects by providing them a large exposure within
> the peer community.
>
> Also, we need people to search for sponsors. For
> example, we may approach coaching classes to sponsor the
> project in return for putting up their ads/banners on our
> default wallpaper, the GNOME/KDE splash screens, the default
> gdm login logo, and the CD covers and the prints on the CD themselves.
>
> Absolutely any help will be appreciated a lot. We would
> like CSLinux to become a living example of an open source
> project that is self-sustaining, started off by students on
> their own, and a successful business model within Pune
> (although it will be strictly not-for-profit).
>
> If you feel that you have completed any assignment from
> BCS/MCS/BE/ME/MCA/Diploma to perfection and would like the
> community to see it, then we will also be including such
> assignments for reference on the distribution. This is a very
> highly-demanded feature by many.
>
> Your contribution on recommendations to what tools,
> packages and documents that should be included in CSL would
> be highly appreciated.
>
> We thank you for all your support in this matter.
>
> For more information you may contact the following:
>
> Amit Karpe: amitkarpe@vsnl.net, 9226745408 Archis Gore:
> archisgore@yahoo.com, 9371058022
>
> It would be preferred if you could post your suggesstions,
> ideas and contributions onto the list.
>
> Thank you,
> Yours sincerely,
> The CSL Team
>
> P.S. Please forward this mail to as many mailing lists and
> people that may be interested.
>
> E-mail: archisgore@yahoo.com
> Homepage: http://www.geocities.com/archisgore
--
blog @ http://toufeeq.blogspot.com
From sbharathi at MidasComm.Com  Thu Mar 30 10:37:56 2006
From: sbharathi at MidasComm.Com (Bharathi Subramanian)
Date: Thu Mar 30 10:35:02 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] TUX OO Tech Tip
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0603301036050.5599-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

TUX OO Tech Tip :-

When you create a template in OpenOffice.org and save the template
with File -> Save As -> Template, the documents you create from that
template aren't associated with it. Therefore, if you change or update
the template, the documents previously created from it don't receive
the updates automatically. Instead, the next time you open a document
created from a template that has been updated, you'll be asked if
you'd like the document to be updated as well.

HTH :)
--
Bharathi S

Hi Anirudh,

>Message: 9

>Subject: [Ilugc] Unable to install

>configure: error: zinf needs zlib installed
>
>*** The glib-config script installed by GLIB could not be found
>*** If GLIB was installed in PREFIX, make sure PREFIX/bin is in
>*** your path, or set the GLIB_CONFIG environment variable to the
>*** full path to glib-config.
>configure: error: *** GLIB >= 1.2.2 not installed - please install first 
>***
>
>*** Warning: No suitable gperf found. ***
>     The gperf package is essential for building ivl from
>     CVS sources, or modifying the parse engine of ivl itself.
>     You can get away without it when simply building from
>     snapshots or major releases.

I presume this is during a ./configure . It means you are missing the glib, 
gperf and flex packages. use "Synaptic" to install the above packages or do 
the following

sudo apt-get install <package name>

Synaptic is a package manager. Also try to do a apt-get dist-upgrade to 5.10 
(Breezy)

For more detailed information on several HOW-to s on installing packages in 
Ubuntu visit http://ubuntuguide.org

For information Dapper release has been postponed to JUNE :(

most desktops have keyboards that you can choose. Kde has a 
provision of two keyboards so one can switch between tamil and 
english. There are two or three standard layouts for each language, 
and most of them are the same, so if you know devnagri for example 
you can happily type gujarati or bengali without knowing a word of 
those languages.

From binand at gmail.com  Thu Mar 30 12:13:03 2006

Subject: [Ilugc] Contribution to FOSS

On 30/03/06, R.Subramanian (RS) <rs2003@gmail.com> wrote:
> The development areas identified are ( mostly addressing our needs)
>
> 1.The lack of a comprehensive sysadmin tool ( Webmin is ok, but is not
> comprehensive)

This is a double-edged sword. I personally distrust any of these
"comprehensive" tools after some bad experiences with linuxconf (way
back in '97 or so). Their main problem is that they simply do not have
the manpower or resources to keep up to date with the vast variety of
software out there. For example, how many mail servers does webmin
support? sendmail? qmail? postfix? exim? courier? Even if it does,
which versions? Does it support sendmail 8.11, 12 and 13 (all three
very common on the internet)?

Recently, I had a chance to work on a "root" server that had come with
Plesk preinstalled. I tried to replace bind on that box with djbdns -
and ran into so much trouble that I have sworn off Plesk now. It took
me the best part of a day to make sure that this Fedora box could run
djbdns while maintaining its RPM database consistent. I blame this
squarely on Plesk - its inability to support djbdns.

> 2. Lack of  comprehensive and efficient documentation & tools

RHEL's documentation is really good - maybe you should base your
efforts on that. Tools - what tools do you have in mind?

Binand

On 3/30/06, Gopalarathnam Venkatesan <gopal@gopalarathnam.com> wrote:
>
> On 3/30/06, Kenneth Gonsalves <lawgon@thenilgiris.com> wrote:
> >
> > also the best ever redhat release
> >
>
> It might be the best ever redhat release, but its way too old and does
> not have support for the latest hardware.


 RH 7.3 is the best distro, out-of-the-box. Anything else requires
significant tweaking to make it work safely. HW support is not really
a limitation of the distro - you can recompile a recent kernel as well
as some userland RPMs to get HW support for anything, on
practically any distro. It's fairly trivial to recompile a recent 2.6.x
kernel and use it on a RedHat  7.3 installation - I used to do that
quite often, but found FC3/FC4  to be equally good and faster,
with some tweaking.

If you're doing a fresh install, use FC3/4/5. For legacy support,
YMMV, but RH 7.3 will work well in under 64 MB of RAM.

-Siva

Dear luggies,

It is indeed painful to see, people see our physical activities as
wasting their bandwidth, time and considered lowly - probably like
the work done by officeboys, peons et.al. But world consists of - not
only ivory tower thinkers, but also lowly mortals like me who
practice FOSS. 

This is not going to stop us doing, nor reporting/discussing on the
mailing list of the physical activities.

If you want the ILUGC community character to be maintained and not
hijacked by few it has to be all encompassing -teach and community
work.

There is a danger - as happened to linuxbangalore - if you allow a
small set of people to do activities offlist. They may register the
ILUGC under law and claim control over it. 

Let there be only one list and only one organisation i.e. ILUGC.

I agree with sakthi to advise people to switch to diegest mode if
they find traffic toomuch.

Raman.P

Message-ID: <a8f990120603300234r137f1906r9991db62244c93d9@mail.gmail.com>

On 3/30/06, Gopalarathnam Venkatesan <gopal@gopalarathnam.com> wrote:
>
>
>
> You're contradicting yourself here... if you are recompiling a recent
> kernel and or a recent release of Xorg, how can it be the best distro
> out-of-the-box.


  Where's the contradiction?  You can use RH 7.3, unmodified,
out-of-the-box, and it's the best distro ever. Or you can recompile the
kernel and some SRPMs for additional HW support or anything else,
and RH 7.3 is still great, and will probably happily run in 64 MB or less.

  OTOH, you can use FC3/FC4 on more recent HW, tweak it a bit,
and get a comparable user experience, with arguably better desktop
responsivity, at some additional cost in RAM (at least 96 MB) and
HD space. BTW, on FC4 it's mandatory that you upgrade gcc and
recompile Xorg, glibc, and lots of other stuff to make it run as
reliably as RH 7.3.

  Or you can start with RH 7.3 and upgrade selectively to FC3/4/5
and still have a small-memory install.

-Siva

will be getting added more and more and everyone will have their own
valid reason for new tags. (Remember that light bulb story about web
forums). I'm not starting another flame war here this is just my point
of view ignore if you feel this is stupid.

For me FLOSS Events, FLOSS/Forum Announcements, Troubleshooting and
even Jobs are on topic for this forum. They don't need a [OT] or any
other tag.

This mailing list is a community mailing list and should not be ruled
with an iron-hand.This *is not* LKML.Any information/query w.r.t FOSS

part should understand that this is a community list first and a tech
list next.

not needed.
If you have something to say to ILUGC this is the *only* avenue.

Having a taxonomy also won't work.Do you want people to lookup a chart
of Subject-tags and choose the right ones ? Those sensible enough will
simply add a [OT] tag.

list for non-tech will leave many uninformed about ilugc activities -
especially when so much good work is being done.

will also happen here. I do not understand why showing 'face' in meetings

FOSS movement are basic requirements to even post ones views in the mailing
list! Surely, no FOSS manual says so!

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Fri Mar 31 04:35:52 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Fri Mar 31 18:06:31 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Diabling parallel port support
In-Reply-To: <a1da1e5e0603310244h6b5a421y733680aad161c8b5@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060331123552.53077.qmail@web50208.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi KaruppuSwamy,

--- KaruppuSwamy T <karuppuswamy@gmail.com> wrote:
> I want to completly remove the parallel port support
> from linux kernel. 
> But I think there will be a kernel command line
> option to do this with no
> need of kernel compilation. Is there any solution
> like that? If it is, how
> to do that.

Pass "parport=0" to the kernel command line in
grub/lilo configuration file. For example:

 kernel /boot/vmlinuz-2.4.21 ro root=LABEL=/ parport=0

Check Documentation/kernel-parameters.txt for more
options:
http://lxr.linux.no/source/Documentation/kernel-parameters.txt

SK

Hi KaruppuSwamy,

--- KaruppuSwamy T <karuppuswamy@gmail.com> wrote:
> Here is the parport related drivers:
> $ lsmod | grep parport
> parport_pc             35236  1
> parport                35912  2 parport_pc,lp

... which means you have it as modular (M) in your
kernel config. Since you also have KMOD enabled, it
overrides your parport=0. That's my assumption.

If you have the driver built-in (*), it shouldn't show
in lsmod.

My kernel config file:

http://www.shakthimaan.com/downloads/debian_t41/config.linux-2.6.12.3.txt

I have parallel port support built-in:

#
# Parallel port support
#
CONFIG_PARPORT=y
CONFIG_PARPORT_PC=y

By default, parallel port support is there.
 
When, I pass parport=0 to kernel line, it doesn't
create the /dev/lp0 device file, and hence I cannot
use the parallel port.

HTH,

SK

From anant at kix.in  Fri Mar 31 22:54:32 2006
From: anant at kix.in (Anant Narayanan)
Date: Fri Mar 31 22:56:42 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [OT] doubt in php
In-Reply-To: <aec5a5f80603310914v2d576150w3390ff9057627028@mail.gmail.com>
References: <aec5a5f80603310914v2d576150w3390ff9057627028@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <442D65D0.8090000@kix.in>

Hi Balachandran,

>                 I have  a doubt in php regarding redirecting...I want
> to redirect to different pages based on the type of the user who logs
> in.... Using the header function doesn't help... Can anybody help.....

If the header() function doesn't work for you (why?) you can try using
HTML's <meta> tag.

if ($someuser) {
    echo "<meta HTTP-EQUIV=\"refresh\" content=2;url=\"somepage.php\">";
} else {
    echo "<meta HTTP-EQUIV=\"refresh\" content=2;url=\"otherpge.php\">";
}

Here the value of content is the number of seconds to wait before the
page refreshes (and hence redirects to another location), and the value
of url is the page you want to redirect to.

Best Regards,
-- 
Anant

Find Freedom! Go Open Source!
http://www.kix.in/

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Fri Mar 31 10:30:31 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Sat Apr  1 00:00:50 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Monthly reminder: Mailing list guidelines
Message-ID: <20060331183031.89319.qmail@web50206.mail.yahoo.com>

Greetings!

This is a monthly reminder to members of this list
about the posting guidelines. Please don't reply to
this e-mail. If you'd like to update it, do it here:

http://www.chennailug.org/wiki/List_Guidelines

1. Use a proper subject line.

2. Do not troll in the mailing list

Link: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_troll

3. For off-topic [OT] messages and general discussions
use ilugc-non-tech@googlegroups.com.

4. Do not top-post:

Link: http://www.caliburn.nl/topposting.html

Example of a top-post:

   Because it messes up the order in which 
   people normally read text.
   > > Why is top-posting 
   > > such a bad thing?
   Top-posting.
   > > What is the most 
   > > annoying thing in e-mail?

Always use bottom-posting.

> What is your name ?
  My name is ILUGC.

5. Do not over-quote:

Example of an over-quote:

>>> On Friday you said
>>>  blah blah blah
>> On Saturday you said
>>  foo foo foo
> On Sunday you said
>  foobar

6. Do not post HTML messages

7. Do not recycle messages

8. Do not send attachments

9. Do not attach obnoxious, nonsensical legal
disclaimers. If your company uses disclaimers, don't
use your company ID for the mailing list.

10. Do not reply to a digest. (If you are in digest
mode and want to reply to a post use ILUGC Gmane blog
interface.

Link:
http://blog.gmane.org/gmane.org.user-groups.linux.ilugc

11. Search for answers for your questions/problems in
google.com or any other search engine before posting
your query to the mailing list.

If any of the above are not clear to you, Please read
the detailed list guidelines:

Link:
http://www.catb.org/~esr/faqs/smart-questions.html

12. Do not post messages in all capital letters. Mails
in CAPS is considered rude and is similar to shouting
during a conversation.

13. If you or your company is into GNU/Linux
migration, or you want help into GNU/Linux migration,
check here:
http://www.chennailug.org/wiki/GNU_Linux_migration

14. If you are looking for GNU/Linux distro CDs please
check here:
http://www.chennailug.org/wiki/CDs_for_Grab

15. Following these guidelines could be helpful
http://people.debian.org/~enrico/dcg/

16. Don't send season's greetings or birthday invites
to the group. Its not mailing list etiquette.

We must use the above guidelines to maintain better
readability, proper archives, efficient bandwidth
usage, etc.

The following message was sent by Ciar?n O'Riordan:

"
Hello everyone.

RMS recently gave a speech about GPLv3 in Italy.  It
was a good speech, and the Q&A was interesting, so I
made a transcript:
http://fsfeurope.org/projects/gplv3/torino-rms-transcript.en.html

I also made a transcript of the long GPLv3
presentation given by Eben Moglen on January 16th,
when the draft of GPLv3 was first released:
http://www.ifso.ie/documents/gplv3-launch-2006-01-16.html

I made these as part of my work on FSFE's project to
assist the GPLv3 consultation process, and I'm sending
the links here because they might be useful for people
who are working on GPLv3 awareness in India.

When the GPLv3 process was launched, there were only
two experts: Stallman and Moglen.  We need information
about GPLv3 to spread to every part of the world, and
we have a time limit, so hopefully the transcripts
will:

1. Maximise the reach of the work of the two experts
2. Provide learning materials to make new experts
(you!)

I also made a transcript of a short (25 minute) GPLv3
presentation which Richard made at FOSDEM in February:
http://www.ifso.ie/documents/rms-gplv3-2006-02-25.html

On the GPLv3 wiki, I've made a page for collecting
similar materials:
http://gplv3.fsf.org/wiki/index.php/Reusable_texts

And more info on FSFE's GPLv3 awareness work can be
found here:
http://fsfeurope.org/projects/gplv3/gplv3.en.html

When I made these materials, I informed many free
software communities in Europe because that's where
I'm active.  I didn't inform the free software
communities in India - I wouldn't know how.  Hopefully
others here who wish to help spread GPLv3 awareness
will find these useful.
"
